DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1989SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1989INCOME TAX (ARRANGEMENTS WITH THE STATES) REPEAL BILL 1989

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night we had just started to discuss the amendment to Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) moved by Senator Stone on behalf of the Opposition. The amendment seeks to put in place a regime with regard to information that may be provided by the Commissioner of Taxation to a number of law enforcement agencies such as the National Crime Authority, the Comptroller-General of Customs and Federal and State police forces. The amendment and the Government's Bill have something in common in that they are in agreement that this material should be able to be provided. They differ in the provisions that they seek to use to do that. The Government has sought a method by which the Taxation Commissioner can, on the Australian Taxation Office's behalf, provide material or information basically if he is satisfied that the information is relevant to:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) establishing whether a serious offence has been, or is being, committed; or
(b) the making, or proposed or possible making, of a proceeds of crime order.

The Opposition, in response, has sought to interpose a method-as I was saying last night-which has been used in quite a number of places, that is, to interpose the legal system between the agency seeking or providing the information and the people who are seeking it or providing it, whichever the exercise is.

Another clear difference between the Government's approach and the Opposition's approach is that the initiative in the Government's Bill is on the side of the Commissioner of Taxation, while the initiative in the Opposition's amendment seems to be clearly on the side of those people seeking the information. It is not clear, either from the Government's amendments in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) or from the Opposition's amendments to the Government's proposals, whether the alternative is acceptable. Basically, the legislation is silent, as is the amendment, on the issue of whether it is possible, under the terms of the Government's Bill, for one of those agencies to simply request the Commissioner for information, and for the Commissioner to then provide that information once the agency has satisfied the criteria set out in the Bill. There does not appear to be any reason why that could not occur under the Government's legislation. The legislation is silent on that matter; hence, one must believe it is possible.

I ask Senator Stone to clarify this, but my reading of the Opposition's amendment is that the fact that a formal request has to be made by the people seeking the information seems to preclude the Taxation Commissioner from actually offering information. I do not know whether that is the intention of the Opposition's amendment. If it is, it raises significant difficulties. In terms of the information and the areas that we are talking about-and we must remember that we are not referring here to a situation in which this material can be used essentially for anything other than intelligence operations-both groups have the ability to access intelligence and information about whether a serious offence has been or, as the legislation provides, is being, committed. I would be very worried if the Opposition's amendment were constructed in such a way. Senator Stone has indicated his wish to speak as to whether the amendment would preclude an operation coming from the other direction.

My second concern about the Opposition's amendment is the time frame. As a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I have some working knowledge of the operations of that Authority and of the time frames that are often involved in reaching a decision. Sometimes the time frame is extremely short. I am particularly worried that the Opposition's approach to this matter could very well rule out the exercise that is included in the Government's proposal-if there is an imminent possibility of a serious offence being committed, it might be stopped or the people who are seeking to perpetrate it, immediately arrested. The Opposition's suggested method seems to imply that that would take considerable time. I ask Senator Stone to respond to that concern.

The third point I wish to make is that when this chamber not so long ago debated the tax file number legislation, which my Party opposed, we debated cognately with it the Privacy Bill 1988. I have, on behalf of my Party, introduced two private members' Bills dealing with this matter and the Bill which was passed was the Government's second attempt at this legislation. So attempts to establish some type of privacy commissioner have a very long history.
Division 2, section 27 (1) of the Privacy Act lists the Privacy Commissioner's functions. I will read out the pertinent functions from that long list:
The Commissioner has . . .

(a) to investigate an act or practice of an agency that may breach an Information Privacy Principle and, where the Commissioner considers it appropriate to do so, to endeavour, by conciliation, to effect a settlement of the matters . . .

(b) when requested to do so by a Minister, to examine the proposed enactment that would require or authorise acts or practices of an agency that might, in the absence of the enactment, be interferences with the privacy of individuals.

In regard to section 27 (1) (b), I ask Senator Tate whether the Government has considered requesting the Privacy Commissioner to examine how this exercise may be accomplished and whether protocols and procedures need to be put in place immediately so that the Australian Taxation Office is provided with guidelines by the Taxation Commissioner as to how to proceed in this matter. Section 27 (1) (h) states:
(h) to conduct audits of records of personal information maintained by agencies for the purpose of ascertaining whether the records are maintained according to the Information Privacy Principles;

I think that is particularly pertinent. As Senator Stone said in moving his amendment last night, recently there have been gross violations of privacy on the part of the Taxation Office. In the last 24 hours I have endeavoured to get hold of the statement made by the Taxation Office with regard to these violations. I have not been able to do so. I ask Senator Tate whether he has a statement on this matter from the Privacy Commissioner. I understand that, in terms of the media report at least, the Privacy Commissioner has now required the Taxation Office to establish a privacy organisation function or person. As I said, I still have not been able to get clear details from anybody as to what has gone on in regard to a particular violation of privacy when a lawyer received information with regard to 35 taxpayers. Senator Tate has indicated that he now has that information.

Those are the problems that we have run into in considering the Opposition's amendment. My initial response to the amendment was certainly favourable. However, looking at it as a member of the Joint Select Committee on the National Crime Authority, I am cognisant of the way in which the Authority operates and, to me, the time frame problem is a very real one. I am sure that neither Senator Stone nor anybody else in this place would be interested in protecting in any way people who have committed or will commit crimes, hence when we put in place a legislative mechanism we have to be reasonably careful to ensure that we do not assist criminal activity. As I say, Senator Stone and the Government, as shown by its amendments, have one thing in common: they believe that we can now move to the situation of providing this information. What we are debating is how to do that. The Australian Democrats are also of the opinion that this information should be provided. I am not sure that the method that the Opposition has chosen will facilitate that matter on the two points that I have just raised. I would like to hear from Senator Stone with regard to those matters, and from Senator Tate on the other matters I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone is engaged in consultation, so I will just mention one or two matters additional to those which I exhaustively went through last night. Was Senator Macklin pointing to section 27 (1) (b) or 28 (1) (b) in the Privacy Act?
—Section 27 (1) (b).
—That provides:

SPEECH.PARA: When requested to do so by a Minister-
the Privacy Commissioner has to-
examine a proposed enactment that would require or authorise acts or practices of an agency that might, in the absence of the enactment, be interferences with the privacy of individuals.
I am getting some information on the actual application of that in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is whether the protocol will be put into place prior to the operation of this.

—We will see what we can do about that. In general, Senator Macklin is correct in suggesting that where there is a strength or an advantage in the Government's proposal it lies in the fact that, quite clearly, we are depending on a cooperative attitude being fostered between the Commissioner of Taxation and the law enforcement agencies. Indeed, it will be the case that when a law enforcement agency is confronted with a particular serious type of criminal activity or, even more clearly, is proceeding upon a proceeds of crime track, it may approach the Commissioner of Taxation and make a request or seek to know whether there is anything held within the Australian Taxation Office which might be of intelligence use to the law enforcement agency. So that is understood to be part of the cooperative, more administrative scheme, as opposed to the court based scheme proposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the misgivings that have arisen in the community concerning the disclosure of taxation information by the Commissioner of Taxation, his officers or, at least, the Taxation Office-inadvertently, I am quite sure, but, nevertheless, negligently and in a way that has harmed the reputation of the Tax Office in regard to the certainty and sureness that information it holds can be maintained confidentially-it is a fact that discussions took place between the Privacy Commissioner and the Commissioner of Taxation very recently. The press release put out by the Privacy Commissioner advising of new Tax Office controls says:

A Privacy Ombudsman will be appointed within the Australian Tax Office to ensure adherence to privacy standards, Federal Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, was advised today. The Taxation Commissioner, Mr Trevor Boucher, advised Mr O'Connor of plans to create the new position at a meeting in Melbourne today.

It goes on with a review of the situation which had developed with, perhaps, the lack of adequate controls over the provision of information from the Tax Office to certain persons. About three paragraphs from the bottom of the first page, the press release says:
The Privacy Ombudsman to be appointed shortly will have special responsibility for ensuring adherence to privacy standards within the Tax Office.

I will try and get the attachment to that press release for Senator Macklin concerning the outline of the advertisement that is to be placed or has been placed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette relating to that particular office within the Tax Office. The lapses in confidentiality need to be overcome. I believe that the appointment of a Privacy Ombudsman within the Tax Office will assist. It has to be constantly emphasised that as far as this Parliament is concerned such a useful administrative arrangement is one that ought to be in place and perhaps ought to have been in place. Nevertheless from the point of view of this Parliament it is the role of the Privacy Commissioner established by statute under legislation passed late last year which is important. As I pointed out, every time the Commissioner of Taxation makes available to a law enforcement agency material concerning Australian taxpayers in a way which would otherwise be an interference with privacy but is justified and would be justified under this legislation then a notation to that effect must appear on the file.

The Privacy Commissioner as required by this Parliament will have access to those files, be able to audit the notated files and will be able, if necessary, to report to the Parliament on any abuse that he discovers in relation to the passage of such legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then what?

—Then the Parliament, being fully informed of the abuse, will be able to take action. As I also pointed out last night, if indeed the Commissioner of Taxation releases information that does not fall within the objectives set by this Parliament, namely, information to do with a serious offence or with respect to proceedings under the proceeds of crime legislation-that is the legislation that confiscates the profits of crime of those convicted of serious offences-the Taxation Commissioner is guilty of a breach of section 16 of the tax Act and will be subjected to very severe penalties. Indeed a mandamus can be sought from the High Court of Australia in order to ensure that the Taxation Commissioner does his duty and keeps within the statutory bounds. What I am saying is that there are procedures available--
—At great cost.

—No, I was putting them as alternatives. The fact is that this Parliament late last year, recognising that a court based approach in this area would be very costly, cumbersome and difficult for people to take advantage of, provided that we really should rely on the Privacy Commissioner and the cheaper administrative arrangements, surveillance and supervision that he can undertake as the preferred method of ensuring adherence to the will of the Parliament in relation to the maintenance of privacy and confidentiality of information given under compulsion, in this case to the Tax Office, as required by law. It is that notation of files and the supervisory role of the Privacy Commissioner which will provide the sort of protection that is required. It will be bolstered somewhat by the appointment of a Privacy Commissioner within the Tax Office. As I said, that is perhaps to protect the standing of the Tax Office which has declined somewhat in the public mind as a result of some recent instances. But as far as the Parliament is concerned it is the reliance on the Privacy Commissioner which is paramount.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond quickly to the couple of questions which were, I think, specifically addressed to me by Senator Macklin. I will have more extensive comments to make about the position of the Minister for Justice at a later stage of the committee debate. Some of my other colleagues want to speak also. I rise momentarily now simply to say that Senator Macklin asked me whether he was correct in his understanding. I hope that if I recall Senator Macklin's questions inaccurately he will assist me because I was being rather harassed at the time by the conversation of other colleagues here on relevant matters. I understood Senator Macklin to ask me first whether his understanding of our amendment was correct in that it would preclude the Commissioner of Taxation acting on his own discretion as distinct from acting only in response to approaches. The answer to that question is yes. That is the intention of the amendment for reasons I have already stated but which I am prepared certainly to elaborate on at a later stage of the committee debate. Secondly, if I understood Senator Macklin's question correctly, he referred to the need at times for law enforcement agencies to have information available to them in an attempt to deal with a crime which they believe is about to be committed-`imminently' is I think the word he used. Senator Macklin is nodding; I appear to have understood him correctly. He indicated that he understood that our amendment would-again I am paraphrasing-provide a significant hindrance to that sense of urgency or imminence.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not quite such an easy question to respond to. If the law enforcement agency really believes that a crime is about to be committed it can go urgently to a Federal judge and urgently seek access to information. All those processes would probably take some hours more-perhaps a day longer in the worst case-than the more straightforward, if I can put it that way, but more objectionable bureaucratic procedure of information simply being passed. It is undoubtedly true that there would be some slight delay in those procedures. We have to accept that in any safeguards which one writes into legislation to protect the liberties of the citizens of this country there are bound to be some costs of that kind. Clearly if our only objective were to set up the most efficient police state we could devise in order to absolutely track down, locate, prosecute and put behind bars every criminal in this country, and we had no regard whatsoever for safeguards of civil liberties in the process, we could devise a much more efficient system for that purpose. Mr Temporary Chairman, through you I put to Senator Macklin that we recognise that there is a slight cost in that regard but see it as a totally appropriate cost to pay, given the objectives we seek to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a little more concern about the matter raised by Senator Macklin. It seems to me, as Senator Stone has said, that Senator Macklin's concerns related to the time frames, if there was an imminent-I think that was his word-possibility of a serious offence being committed. As I read the explanatory memorandum, on page 26 it specifically seems to exclude the very point that I think Senator Macklin was making. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Broadly, proposed section 3e provides the Commissioner of Taxation with a discretion to disclose taxation information to an authorised law enforcement agency officer. Such disclosure is conditional on the Commissioner being satisfied that the information is relevant to the investigation of a serious offence or post-conviction confiscation and restraining order proceedings. The information may be disclosed by the Commissioner of Taxation either on his own initiative or in response to a request by an authorised law enforcement agency officer. The Commissioner cannot be compelled to reveal information. Information disclosed under section 3e may only be used for investigation purposes except where it relates to confiscation and restraining order proceedings in relation to a person convicted of a serious offence.
The second half of that would not involve any urgency in the sense that it would relate to a serious offence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intelligence part? For investigatory purposes?

—As Senator Macklin intervenes, the bit that concerns him is that which says `may only be used for investigation purposes'. As I understood the investigation purposes proposition, the urgency related to that surely would be limited, if it is for investigation purposes, to a response presumably by the officer or crime agency involved. Is Senator Macklin expressing concern that the Commissioner on his own initiative would encourage investigation? I raise that because it seems to me that to add this to the Commissioner's many discretions raises serious problems indeed. It has already been alleged that the Commissioner has made threats to people in terms of coming to deals on taxation matters. It would really worry me if we were to give an added discretion to the Commissioner, to give him the power, if you like, to say, `Look, if you don't resolve this matter I will refer it to another body or to someone else and I will encourage investigation'. I think that there is a cost-benefit in this.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not saying that the Commissioner will naturally behave disgracefully; all I am saying is that there may well be a temptation to whoever is the Commissioner to use this as an additional piece of clout in his relationship with the taxpayer who may well feel in these circumstances that he should give way to the Tax Commissioner's request, having been pressured like this. Frankly, I am concerned about giving the Tax Commissioner additional clout in this area. I clearly take the view that in any event for a large part of this activity there is no prospect of urgency. In respect of the part where it may only be used for investigation purposes, I would need to be convinced that an investigation would be dangerously inhibited by protecting the rights and secrecy of ordinary citizens of Australia, given the assertions by Senator Macklin and admissions by the Minister that the Taxation Office has abused the trust that has been put in it in terms of secrecy and that it has done so to a considerable extent.

I recognise that no-one is perfect and that prosecutions and all sorts of other activities may well proceed, but I do think that it is unreasonable to ask us to adopt a cost-benefit approach to this matter when we have yet to see the material that Senator Macklin called for and when, in fact, it seems to me that the sense of urgency may possibly apply only to a proportion of the information that the Commissioner may be inclined to reveal to other law enforcement agencies. Unless I was absolutely convinced that the cost-benefit lay totally and overwhelmingly with this proposed change in the law, I would need far more convincing arguments than I have heard today to go along with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take Senator Michael Baume's point with regard to the second part of the proposition; that is, of a person who has been convicted. Fairly obviously, the only urgency that would be available in terms of the types of things I was saying, is in the investigatory role or what the Minister referred to as providing material with regard to intelligence about the possible commission of a crime. I will refer to the second point first: Senator Baume has expressed concern with regard to the additional power provided to the Taxation Commissioner. He was suggesting that there should be an additional lever when there was no cooperation from a particular person. I probably agree. While the intent of the legislation may not be that, I can foresee that powers, once given, tend to be used if they are available. Clause 3e (3) states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where information is communicated to a person under subsection (1) or (2), the person:
(a) shall not voluntarily give the information in evidence in a proceeding before a court; and
(b) shall not be required to divulge or communicate the information to a court.

That may put a significant bar on wanting to go down that track. We could end up jeopardising an otherwise decent case against a person. This is the trade-off which we discussed recently in regard to the corporations legislation and which applies to a whole range of similar areas. On almost every occasion that we lean towards providing information, the Parliament has said that that information cannot be used to get a conviction. Law enforcement agencies will have to weigh up the pros and cons of how they will use the information-but not information derived from obtaining it-because providing it may rule out the conviction of someone in a court. Clause 3e (3) might be a sufficient bar to the type of situation which Senator Michael Baume raised. I, too, am interested in the Minister's response. I think it is an important point.

Senator Stone indicated that my interpretation of the Opposition amendments-that it is only a one-way street-was correct. That aspect of the Opposition's amendments concerns me. Essentially, it is a move away from the law enforcement agencies to the Taxation Commissioner. I have been concerned about that for a long time, particularly since serving on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. The Authority has to know what information the Taxation Commissioner has before it can ask him for it. The Authority, under the current legislation, is not permitted to go on a fishing expedition-and quite rightly. The Opposition's amendments propose to maintain that regime. It seems to me that we are being unduly harsh on ourselves in the fight against crime. Where the Taxation Commissioner may have information, he ought to tell the law enforcement agencies that he believes that a crime is about to be committed. That is precisely what the legislation before us provides for. I have felt for a long time that that was needed. I have not yet heard a sufficient argument from the Opposition which would weigh against that.

If honourable senators read the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on its inquiry into drugs, crime and society-although probably not many have been able to do so because of the busy time we have had in the chamber-they will be only too aware that we are facing a most horrific battle against crime which is being funded by billions of dollars from the drug trade. I am cognisant of the matters raised by Senator Stone. I am as worried as he is about how far we should go. I agree totally with his point that we could establish a police state and probably pick up most criminals, but it would not be the type of state any of us would want to live in.

This is an area where we have to make very fine judgments. Unfortunately, the principles which are in conflict do not give us much of a lead. My experience from having served on the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority has led me to believe that a properly controlled exercise with regard to information held by the Taxation Commissioner could be of massive benefit to many of our law enforcement agencies. The Opposition has not agreed that the information should be so provided; we are just talking about what the proper controls should be.

I am still inclined to support the Government's proposition, not only for the reasons I have already outlined but also because, if the Privacy Commissioner's role can be enhanced by the actions of further legislation in this Parliament, it can become an extremely powerful office. TALK.START.PARA: —Where are you reading from, Senator?

SPEECH.PARA: As to the question of urgency and the initiative being taken by the Taxation Commissioner to provide information to law enforcement agencies, this is an important point. TALK.START.PARA: —I am appalled at the situation. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot speak for Senator Stone, who I assume will be in the chamber shortly. I have no doubt that he would not mind the Bill being stood over until Tuesday under any circumstance. —But you would be interested in what the Privacy Commissioner had to say.

I find it objectionable that we have provisions of this nature, which ought to stand alone, attached to a technical Bill almost as an addendum. When I was in my office Senator Macklin raised the question of the Opposition's position with respect to the Commissioner being able to initiate the provision of legislation as distinct from its being solicited from him, which is the essence of our amendment. Of course, that is the clear distinction between our position and that of the Government. Senator Macklin was quite right when he said that powers, once given, are not given in some sort of socially acceptable way; they are not used with some moral guideline weighing heavily upon the shoulders of the person who has the capacity to use the information. Once powers are given, they are invariably and inevitably used as a negotiating chip to the extremities of the interpretation of the powers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation has demonstrated that. The Rambo-type raids on merchant banks demonstrate that the Commissioner of Taxation will test his powers right to the very edges. Whilst I exclude Senator Macklin-and he will understand that-certain senators within this chamber very dearly hold unto themselves a reputation as being civil libertarians, but whenever they are confronted with situations such as this, they are the first to argue that the onus ought to be removed from the investigating officers and cast in the opposite direction.

On reading this Bill, I can see no distinct guidelines or parameters for the Commissioner of Taxation. It is based very much on a subjective judgment, a state of mind. The Commissioner of Taxation may receive evidence which may be peripheral, inconclusive and not substantial but which may lead him, in a subjective way, to conclude that his providing the information is relevant to establishing whether a serious offence has been or is being committed, or is relevant to a possible proceeds of crime order. These are very much matters in the mind of the Commissioner of Taxation simply on the basis of what evidence is incidentally available to him. One might ask: With what knowledge, with what judgment, and on what basis, would the Commissioner of Taxation draw the conclusion that information on his files is information which, if provided to a law enforcement agency, would establish whether a serious crime had been committed?

As Senator Stone has said, quite correctly, we could introduce into the Australian community a watchdog system which would no doubt dramatically reduce the levels of crime. But at what price? Banks and almost every government agency, as well as private institutions, would be able to provide information to law enforcement agencies. We could even take it a step further: we could compel them to provide information to the law enforcement agencies if that information led them subjectively to conclude that the commission of a serious offence may be established. We could make it compulsory-which is just a further step away. We have seen the price that some people have already had to pay in terms of inquiries based on very inadequate and poor information and as a result of subjectivity in drawing conclusions. On my reading of the Bill, the Taxation Ombudsman would be in no serious way a caveat upon the conduct of the Commissioner of Taxation, who could always retreat on the basis, in his mind, that information he had was relevant.

There is a very clear distinction between the Government's position and our view that there ought to be a reason for the information to be required by an authorised law enforcement agency, and that reason ought to be that information the agency has received causes it to seek information from the Commissioner of Taxation. Fundamentally, that is the very clear difference between the two of us.

SPEECH.PARA: I object to what is happening here. We want to see the provision severely amended. We want to see the authority taken out of the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation so that he does not have the discretion to divulge this information, even to other law enforcement agencies. We want to see it at least oversighted by a judge. The Australian Taxation Office has had troubles with its information lately. TALK.START.PARA: —The office in Western Australia leaked like a sieve.

—I am sorry-I have not moved my amendment as I was raising a separate issue in committee with regard to the section on the disability allowance. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, paragraph 14 (b), after proposed subparagraph 78 (1) (a) (xciv), add the following new subparagraph:
`` `(xcv) the Nursing Mothers' Association of Australia;'.''.

My amendment was previously circulated in regard to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), but I have now moved it to this Bill because the Government has sought to amend that section with regard to two other items in this legislation. The Government is seeking to include two funds in the list of charities: first, the public fund for the Armenian earthquake victims, which will run only from the time the earthquake occurred until 1 July this year; and secondly, the Australian-Ireland Fund. The fact that my father is Irish leads me to support that provision. My amendment also seeks to include another organisation, the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia. As honourable senators would probably be aware, particularly the women in the chamber, this is the second largest women's organisation in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the largest, the CWA?

—Yes, the Country Women's Association. The Nursing Mothers Association now has more than 1,600 trained breastfeeding counsellors and I am informed that there are about 800 trainee counsellors currently undertaking training. There are nearly 600 groups around the country, and last year nearly a quarter of a million women were counselled on breastfeeding. That may not seem an important item to the Government, but when we look at the structure of our society, we find that when many women have their first and subsequent children, they have very little support. Previously the social structure was such that sisters, aunts or even mothers may have been available, but now there is very little support during what is a very difficult time for young mothers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Nursing Mothers Association provides not only information with regard to breast feeding but also that social support that is necessary. Indeed counsellors-I know this from personal experience as my wife has operated as a counsellor for some considerable time-have to deal not only with inquiries with regard to breastfeeding but often with much more difficult situations as well, particularly when a child may have been crying for 10 or 15 hours and the mother is at breaking point. Those are the types of social situations where child abuse can often occur. I think this is exacerbated by the isolation that mothers can feel within our community.

I now specifically direct my attention to the breastfeeding activities of the Association. The Government has been very supportive of the Association, at least in words, but its actions have been very detrimental to it. The working party that the Government established to implement the World Health Organisation's International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes, which reported in March 1985, said:
this organisation-
that is, the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia-
has had a major influence in reversing the trend of the 1960s and early 1970s away from breastfeeding.

This also may not seem to be terribly important to the Government, but the economic ramifications might be interesting to Senator Walsh. I have done some calculations of the number of counselling calls that have been undertaken by the Nursing Mothers Association. If the 1,500 voluntary counsellors, who do not cost the community a penny, were not there to give those counselling calls, and if only one in 10 of those women sought counselling from a doctor rather than the Nursing Mothers Association, the cost to Medicare would be $800,000. I am sure that neither of the two funds that the Government has included in the legislation can make that claim; in fact, they can claim only to cost money. But by including the Nursing Mothers Association, the Government would help to support an organisation which, if it were not there and only one in 10 of its clients went to doctors, would effectively mean a cost of $800,000 to the community.

More importantly, I think the whole notion of preventative medicine in Australia is extremely important. I do not intend to go through a long list-although I could if honourable senators wished me to do so-of the beneficial effects of breastfeeding. I am referring to a compilation of the information in all the latest medical journals from around the world which have shown, unequivocally, three major benefits. The first is improved health and reduced morbidity in breastfeeding infants. If that is not a major gain to the community, nothing else is. Secondly, there is reduced likelihood of numerous diseases and disorders in young children and of a later onset of those diseases and disorders. Thirdly, there are positive effects on mothers' reproductive systems with a lessening risk of later disorders. It seems to me that there is an overwhelming case for the promotion of breastfeeding. Indeed, the Government accepts that.

We are dealing with a voluntary organisation of women-an organisation which does not cost the taxpayer a penny because its last grant was withdrawn. That organisation is determined to continue its efforts in this regard, to expand and to continue its good work. What it is asking is that it merely be included as a charity so that its fundraising activities will be able to attract the same type of support that the Australian-Irish Association and the victims of the Armenian earthquake will receive as a result of this legislation.

The Association has been active for quite some time and I am surprised that it has not been included in the legislation. Requests have been made over a number of years for that to occur but no action has been taken. The Association should not have to wait any longer. The Government has withdrawn the last $70,000 which was being used for training women to give counselling. As I have said, over the years that has effected massive savings for Medicare. The least we can do is say to the association that we will treat it at least as seriously as the Australian-Irish Association and some of the other organisations that currently receive this advantage-for example, the Australian Administrative Staff College, the Royal Australasian College of Physicians, the Australiana Fund, the Herbert Evatt Memorial Foundation Fund, the Victorian Arts Centre Trust, the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Fund, the Connellan Airways Trust, the national parks and the Work Skill Australia Foundation Inc. If it is worthwhile continuing to activate this part of the legislation-and the Government has seen that as being worthwhile-it is worthwhile activating it with regard to the Nursing Mothers Association. I hope that the amendment will have the support of all honourable senators, displaying from this chamber at least, and hopefully the Government, that we are very much appreciative of the enormous work being done by the second largest women's organisation in this country.

This is not an issue which has just come up; it is a longstanding issue. As far as I can see, the work that this organisation is doing has the support of all senators. There is acknowledgment that the money has been removed and an acknowledgment that this organisation is a charity which is doing magnificent work in the community and should have been included in these provisions. Are we going to wait for the Government to take another two, three or four years to get its act in order, or are we going to act on behalf of the organisation? This is not an issue which has been sprung on honourable senators; everybody knows about this organisation, and honourable senators have probably come into contact with it themselves. I certainly know Senator Walters has because she has spoken in this place in support of it. She is very much aware of the organisation and is a great supporter of it. It is not a matter of not understanding what this organisation does; it is not a matter of not understanding that this is a problem which has existed for a long time; and it is not a matter of not believing that this is a worthwhile organisation which saves government money. I do not understand the Government's reluctance to include this organisation in these provisions.

I wish to refer to the last point that Senator Patterson raised-which was a good point-that there ought to be a general review of this legislation. Senator Patterson may be interested to know that before she took her seat in this place there was a debate on this topic-and I can give her the reference to it in Hansard-during which that suggestion was made. The Government accepted it and nothing happened. All the Government has done with this Bill is to bring in another two items.

TALK.START.PARA: —Change the Government.
—I am blaming the Government, but I am saying--
—No, I said, `Change the Government'.
—That is a good idea. However, we cannot just say that this is the Government's fault, because this chamber has the power and the numbers to insert this provision in this legislation.
—No, it has not; the other place has that.

—The other place is coming back, and it will take this suggestion in; there is no way it would knock it back. The honourable senator knows as well as I do that in this instance the Government knows it is saving money. It is certainly not going to knock back something on which it is saving money.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the legislation will come into force at the time that is required by the Government, since the other place will undoubtedly support an amendment along these lines because of the very small amount of money which is initially involved and the very large amount of money which has been saved to the community, and since the organisation has a very beneficial effect throughout the community, it seems to me that this suggestion should not be put aside. It is an issue which has been going on for a long time. I think now is the time to come to grips with it and to force the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh said that, from his recollection of a meeting, the Australian Ireland Fund was something to do with the bicentennial year. Can he inform the Committee whether the hundreds of other funds and organisations such as the Australian American Association, United Kingdom or Scottish associations-indeed, the Australian China Society-already get the benefit that it is proposed the Australian-Ireland Fund should receive?

—I forgot earlier to answer Senator Macklin's question about what is now called the disabled child allowance. It was previously called the handicapped child allowance. The change of name was made in November 1987. Neither the previous allowance nor the present allowance is taxable, which is what I would have expected. The amendment ensures that children who receive what is now called the disabled child allowance will not come within division 6aa, which imposes a higher rate of tax on the unearned income of minors, that being a provision which, I think, was introduced by the Fraser Government. If the unearned income of minors exceeds $416 a year, it is taxed at the maximum personal rate. This is, of course, an anti-tax avoidance measure.

—That clarifies, certainly a lot better than the explanatory memorandum managed to do, what the intent was. I hope that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will ask in future-particularly on these issues which affect people in the community and which ordinary people are likely to want to know about-that the explanatory memorandum actually attempt to explain something rather than confuse people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise because Senator Stone interjected when I was speaking earlier and, in relation to the amount of money that is spent by companies on advertising, said, `It still costs them 61c'. I want to make this point yet again. If there is to be a review of the tax deductable nature of public interest bodies-of which this is one-I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) and the Government to take into account the principle of the level playing field in relation to private companies advertising ostensibly their product but in fact advertising a lifestyle of which their product is a part. That is clearly evident in relation to artificial formulae for infant feeding. The companies which sell those products are promoting a view of what is desirable in relation to the nutrition of infants such that the consumption of their product is increased. Those companies promoting that view of the relationship between mother and child and infant nutrition receive tax deductable status for putting that point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Organisations such as the Nursing Mothers Association are putting forward an alternative view that breastfeeding is desirable for children. They have nothing to gain personally from that. What they gain is their share of the common good; yet they are penalised because the donations they receive come from individuals who make those donations after tax has been charged on their income. So it is not a level playing field. I think the Government, in considering the review which has been suggested by Senator Patterson, should look to this matter and ask itself whether those bodies which are furthering the public interest should not get exactly the same tax deductable status as advertisers promoting a particular view of a particular lifestyle such that consumers increase their consumption of their products and they profit. Advertisers have a great deal to gain from putting that point of view. The Nursing Mothers Association has nothing to gain individually from putting its point of view other than the better health of the Australian community. That principle of the level playing field, to which so many people pay lip service, needs to be recognised in this area of tax deductability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter which has been raised by the amendment moved by Senator Macklin relates to section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-the deductability of gifts provision. For my sins, I have some knowledge of that provision. It has been one of the most contentious, time-consuming and difficult areas of the tax law for many years, probably ever since it was first put into the tax Act. Of course, there is no lack of good causes. We can all think of probably half a dozen bodies which we happen to think are excellent worthy bodies performing useful or vital public services. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-I do not always praise the Minister, but I do on this occasion-very fairly said that there is a degree of arbitrariness. I think that is acknowledged on all sides. It is certainly acknowledged by the beleaguered Treasury and Australian Taxation Office officials who have to preside over the administration of the tax law.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, one might well ask: Why should the chamber not support the body to which Senator Macklin wishes to direct the bounty of the taxpayers of Australia? We should not neglect to understand that, when we provide for the deductability of gifts in the tax law, we are basically providing a concession to those who make those gifts, in terms of their taxpaying proclivities, at the expense of other taxpayers. We may be able to make out a perfectly good case for doing that in some cases but, if we are to have people such as Senator Coulter advancing the argument about a level playing field-I must confess that I could not quite follow his argument on that point-I think we need to go a bit more deeply into it than I suggest Senator Coulter did.
It is no good bringing up amendments of this kind at the last minute. I did hear Senator Macklin say that this amendment has been around for a month or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been around for years.

—It may have been around for years in one sense of the term `been around'. But, having the responsibility for the handling of this legislation on behalf of the Opposition, I am concerned that this amendment arrived on my desk only yesterday. I hope that I will not be contradicted in that respect. At no time, either prior to that time or since, did Senator Macklin or any other member of the Australian Democrats speak to me about their intentions in this regard. Had they done so it might have been possible, in the limited time available, to give some consideration to it-although I rather doubt it because the time would have been too limited. It is no good the Democrats coming into this chamber and saying that something has been around for a month, a year, or whatever the time is supposed to be, when we have received a specific proposal only within the last 24 hours. If we are to have good government in this country we simply cannot handle matters of that kind on the run.

SPEECH.PARA: To make an obvious point, I do not imagine that the Minister has had time-in fact I am sure that he has not-to undertake the kinds of processes that he would have to undertake with his Cabinet colleagues, or at any rate a sufficiently senior group of them, to give him authority to agree to an amendment of this kind. I make that point only to draw the obvious parallel that the Opposition has not had sufficient time either. We have had no time to put a proposal of this kind to our shadow Cabinet. It would be the responsibility of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), to do so anyway; it is not my responsibility. There is no time and there will not be an opportunity now, because the House of Representatives has risen, to have a party room discussion on the matter.

We have here a classic example of the behaviour of the Australian Democrats on so many areas where it is a matter of all care and no responsibility. The Democrats come into this chamber time and again putting themselves forward as the caring representatives of the people. But the fact of the matter is that the Democrats have no responsibility for the government of this country. They will come into this chamber and support amendments twice a day every day of the week. This amendment happens to be a terribly minor one and I am not suggesting that it would ruin the country if it were to be incorporated into the tax law; of course it would not. Indeed, Democrat speakers would argue that it would be good for the country, and I am not denying that. They have a perfectly valid case in that respect. But it is not good enough for them to put themselves forward as a responsible political party, yet day after day, week after week, month after month and year after year wheel up to this chamber proposals to spend the taxpayers' money and, therefore, tax the taxpayers a lot more than they are presently taxed, in order to do all the things that the Democrats think should be done, or at least have put forward as things they think should be done, when they have no responsibility whatsoever for the consequences.

This afternoon we will be debating a matter of public importance, the terms of which I think have already been circulated, in which we will be talking about the disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on home buyers, small businesses and farmers. I do not want to get onto that matter; we will have something to say about that later today. I am simply making the point that this is a characteristic modus operandi on the part of the Australian Democrats. Frankly, I think it is time they grew up.

My senatorial colleague Senator Harradine has also supported the amendment. I am inclined to take Senator Harradine's remarks on these matters a good deal more seriously than I am often prepared to concede in the case of the Australian Democrats. But he said that all the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia is asking is to be registered as a charity, so to speak-I think I have quoted him correctly; I took down his words at the time-in order not to be subject to a double whammy. As has been pointed out by Senator Macklin and reiterated by Senator Harradine, the point about the double whammy arose from the fact that this group has been deprived by the Government of a previous grant-in-aid of $73,000. I have to say that the logic of that escapes me. One can argue about whether that grant should have been withdrawn. I think there is a prior question as to the level at which the Government should be making such grants to all these individual associations or organisations in Australia. I think the process of having everything happening from Canberra-all these great tentacles stretching out from Canberra with bits of money being dribbled out here, there and everywhere because some Commonwealth parliamentarian or Minister thinks he can pick up a vote or two in the process-is a recipe for fiscal disaster of the kind that we are now experiencing in this country. We would all be better employed if we put the responsibility for aid of this kind elsewhere.

I do not want to debate the question of whether the association as such is a perfectly worthy object of such aid. It may well be; in fact, I am sure that in many ways it is. What I am saying is that there is a perfectly good case for saying that such aid should come from a State government, not the Commonwealth Government.

I come back to the double whammy argument. Senator Harradine's argument is not correct. It is subject to a single whammy by withdrawal of the grant, but nothing else has happened. No double whammy is involved. I think we have to get our line of argument straight.

Finally, in the light of all considerations I mentioned earlier, we simply cannot handle matters of this kind in the manner in which the Australian Democrats would like us to. The Opposition will not be able to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The issue that I raised was a serious one, but Senator Stone, in his rather tedious way, has decided to make it a political one. It is rather fascinating that he wants to preach about the receipt of amendments, but he has no intention of abiding by those types of rules himself. I have in front of me a copy of amendments dated 8 June which stretch to seven pages. Were we given notice? No; we were asked to support seven pages of amendments on a complex issue with no notice. What is good for the goose is good for the gander, but not for Senator Stone. But everybody should know about the final bias he revealed. He was much more supportive of the comments that Senator Harradine made than of those I made, on the basis of his own personal prejudices. If he wants to conduct his response to legislation in that way, that is his prerogative. But the little preaching about holier than thou and who is giving who notice of amendments is a bit difficult to take when one receives seven pages of amendments on an issue that I took seriously, because I thought it was a serious proposition, and on which I sought an adjournment so that further consideration could be given. I do not know whether any honourable senators want to say that I did not take the issues that they raised seriously; I did. All I have been asking is that I might get in return a serious consideration, not a prejudiced consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible to consider these matters. As this has been going on for so long, I would have thought that the Opposition would have had a view about this particular matter. That particular amendment was sent to the Government and the Opposition three days ago as an amendment to a separate Bill. I explained that it was an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). It was far more appropriate to move that to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). The advice I was given was that the amendment should relate to Bill No. 2. That advice turned out to be wrong; it should have been No. 3. The actual motion was there in people's hands. The Opposition expects us to respond to those types of propositions from it and we seek to do so. Whether the House of Representatives is here or not, this chamber is going to continue on with its legislation and, presumably, continue to consider possible amendments. All I am asking is that when we put up an amendment it be given due consideration. More time was available to consider a one-line amendment than we were given to consider seven pages of amendments. If I had not taken that seriously, I am quite sure that I would have been attacked by Senator Stone. All I am asking in this place is that we consider the propositions on the basis on which they are put forward and not on the basis of personal prejudices.

TALK.START.PARA: -Senator Macklin indicated that, before I came into the Parliament, an undertaking had been given by the Government for a review of organisations eligible for tax deductability. I ask the Minister for Finance whether that is the case. If the Government on a previous occasion has given an undertaking for this review, when will the Government be undertaking that review? In light of the fact that the Minister indicated today that there needed to be some review of organisations, when will the Government be undertaking such a review and when could the outcome of that review be expected?

—I cannot remember whether undertakings have been given in the past or not. If these sorts of things have come up in this chamber before, I may well have said something myself. Frankly, I do not remember. To my knowledge, there is not anything that could be formally called a review under way. I take for granted that such matters are under annual scrutiny to some degree by members of the Treasury Taxation Policy Division or the Australian Taxation Office as a matter of ongoing practice.

-If that is the case, would the Minister be prepared to make a statement to this chamber at some stage about that process of review and the organisations that have been reviewed in that automatic processing referred to?
—I am not the Treasurer. I cannot initiate reviews in the Australian Taxation Office or the Treasury Taxation Policy Division. I will pass that on to the Treasurer.
—I asked the Minister for Finance a question a few minutes ago that he has not yet answered.
—I said I don't know. I told you that.

—No, the Minister did not say that he did not know. Could the question be referred to the bureaucrats sitting beside him? I am sure they would know whether that was the case. Why is the Australian-Ireland Fund being chosen out of all the funds?

—I do not know for how much longer this farce is going to go on. We have spent about an hour debating what, by any reasonable assessment, has to be regarded as a fairly trivial matter. It says something about the priorities and commonsense of not the entire chamber but some of the people in it. I do not know the answer to that question. I will ask the Treasurer to supply an answer at some time. If Senator Walters does not want donations to the Australian Ireland Fund to be on the list, I suggest that she move an amendment to remove it.

—I find the Minister's attitude incredible. Are the bureaucrats who are advising him on this Bill completely unaware whether, all similar funds having already been included, the Australian-Ireland Fund was the only one not included and, therefore, is now to be included? If the Minister does not know, then I suggest that we report progress until the Government finds out.

—If a mother chooses to breastfeed her infant, would the Minister for Finance agree that no costs are involved in the purchase of any equipment and that the mother is not making a contribution to the gross domestic product? On the other hand, if a mother chooses not to breastfeed her infant and goes out and buys artificial formula to feed the infant, does the amount that she spends on that artificial formula go down as an addition to gross domestic product? On the economically driven measures that this Government and Opposition use perhaps the Minister would accept that there are advantages to the Government from women giving up breastfeeding and taking up artificial feeding.

—The farce deepens. If I remember correctly, it was asserted that if a woman goes out and buys prepared foodstuffs for an infant, that is an addition to gross domestic product. The answer is that it is not necessarily an addition to gross domestic product. It may or may not be. I suppose if we are to become really absurd and self-indulgent we could have a discussion about definitions of economic jargon. If, for example, that purchase called into production resources previously unemployed and other things remained equal it would represent an addition to gross domestic product. If it caused a transfer of resources from the production of some other end product it would not. It could be anywhere between the two.
—The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Macklin be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, against say no.
—I have no ambition to spend more time on this Bill.
—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. Mr Chairman you put the question. I do not think you called it.
—Senator Crichton-Browne rose before I had a chance to make a decision on the question.

—I have no wish to prolong this debate or to hold up this legislation past that necessary in the process of reasonable discussion. However, I find it remarkable that we have a Bill before us and that of all the voluntary organisations that make application, as Senator Walsh has said they come to him and to all of us, seeking a tax deduction status, the Australian Ireland Fund pops up. It is not explained in the memorandum. It is not explained by the Minister for Finance and it is not able to be explained by the bureaucrats. I find it remarkable that we are being asked, on the judgment of the Government without explanation, to support this particular fund as being one more deserving than any other. I would not purport to make a value judgment as to whether it is more important than others. But I would have thought that before the Parliament passes legislation giving a priority the Government ought to be offering some sort of justification for that priority. I am sure a case can be made out by all of us. As Senator Walsh says, we could find on our files those other funds, organisations, associations and bodies which have made representations to us and asked that we make representations to the Treasurer that they have a tax deduction status. We are presented here with the Australian-Ireland Fund without any justification and explanation whatsoever and clearly without the Minister knowing why it is in the Bill in the first place except his recollection that he has some vague knowledge of some distant Cabinet meeting.

—Contrary to Senator Walters's belief, advisers from the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of the Treasury do not know every detail. They are unable to recite from beginning to end the Income Tax Assessment Act and they do not know every detail.
—I have it all here.

—Senator Watson spends a lot of time studying it but I bet he cannot recite it from beginning to end either, let alone know every detail of everything that is affected by it. However, the question asked has been checked. Associations similar to the Australian Irish Society which would include the Australia China Friendship Society-I do not know how many others there are-are not on the list qualifying for taxation deductions. I repeat that if Senator Walters does not like that I suggest she move an amendment to remove from this Bill the provisions which provide to the Australian Irish Society that concession.

—Senator Walsh has at last found out that the bureaucrats obviously knew and did not want to answer it. But if they did go away and find out I congratulate the Minister for Finance on being able to get his bureaucrats to whip out and make a phone call. We have the situation now where I do not know, the Committee does not know, the Minister does not know and the bureaucrats do not know. Nobody knows why the Australian Ireland Fund has been chosen out of all these funds to get a benefit that no-one else is entitled to. The Minister says it is a minutia. It is not to all the other funds which have been left out. It might be a minutia to the Minister at the table but I can assure him we will get flak from all the other funds. I am not prepared to say to an Australian United Kingdom fund or an Australian American fund, `Sorry, mate, you haven't had the hand put on you by the Government and the Senate supports that'. I would like a little more information as to why the Australian-Ireland Fund has been chosen, apart from the Minister's vague memory. I am sure that the bureaucrats understand what the situation is and they will be able to jog the Minister's memory.

-I do not often agree with Senator Walters. In fact I cannot remember the last time. But this is certainly a case on which I agree with her wholeheartedly. A reason should be given. From the point of view of the amendment we are discussing I am quite sure the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia is very keen to know why somebody else has been chosen and it has not. I am not speaking against the Australian Irish Society and I have no intention of moving to take it out. Senator Walters is not asking for that either. All she is asking is: why is it included? That is a perfectly reasonable question to ask and to get an answer for.
—You have had an answer.
—The Committee has been told by the Minister for Finance that we have had an answer.
—You got an answer almost an hour ago. If you are too stupid to understand it's not my fault.

—The Committee does not believe that it has had an answer. It is of no use the Minister saying that he has given an answer. He has not given an answer. He has said, `From a vague recollection I have-it was some time ago-I think it must be something to do with the bicentennial functions. I don't really know and don't hold me to it'. That is not a suitable answer for the Committee to be given on a piece of legislation. Again I ask the Minister to ask his bureaucrats beside him what is the reason the Government has chosen the Australian Ireland Fund.
—The Treasurer made a recommendation which the Treasurer is entitled to do. As I recall it the Treasurer made a recommendation to Cabinet.
—On what grounds?
—I have answered that already.
—We have not understood. The whole of the Committee believes that Senator Walsh has not given an answer.
—Your stupidity is your misfortune; it's not my fault.
—Order! There will not be a debate by interjection.

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. The Minister has interjected on two occasions now calling Senator Walters `stupid' or saying `because she was too stupid to understand'. I believe that is a reflection on Senator Walters and I ask you to ask him to withdraw those remarks.
—The remarks should be withdrawn.
—I withdraw.
—I again ask the Minister to ask the bureaucrats whether it is only that the Treasurer would rather have the Australian Ireland Fund get the benefit above all the others.

—For the third time: it was a recommendation from the Treasurer and that is what the public servants alongside me have just confirmed. They told me about half an hour ago which information I passed on, on at least one previous occasion. I pass it on again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —May I make a procedural suggestion? We are, as I think has been previously agreed, deferring further consideration of a major matter on this Bill-namely, the Opposition's amendments to clause 28, I think it is-until next week so that the Government may give further consideration to the amendments the Opposition has moved in that area. I think it is not unfair to say that the Minister for Finance has a somewhat obstreperous attitude towards the questions being asked of him by my colleague Senator Walters which are perfectly proper questions.

SPEECH.PARA: Without in any way questioning the fact that this proposal for tax deductability for gifts to the Australian-Ireland Fund is in the Bill because the Government has taken the decision to put it in the Bill and because the Treasurer put a submission to Cabinet to obtain that purpose, nevertheless the question that Senator Walters is putting is: why is it that this fund which signifies an association with Australia of a foreign country-I am not sure I should call Ireland a foreign country-has been chosen when in fact there is no other comparable provision in section 78 of the gifts deductability provisions in the Principal Act. I think that is a perfectly proper question on Senator Walters's part. I suggest that this is a procedural matter. Speaking on behalf of the Opposition, I suggest to the Minister, through you, Mr Chairman, that when we come back we accept this procedure rather than continue what at the moment seems to be a somewhat fruitless exchange of views across the chamber. We will accept the Minister's assurance that when he comes back next week to discuss the Opposition amendment he will at that time provide an explanation in response to Senator Walters's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the public servants that this was the recommendation of the Treasurer. The public servants are not inside the Treasurer's mind and cannot divine his reasons. I cannot undertake to give any explanation. For a start, I do not know any reasons behind it and, secondly, I do not accept the implied assertion that the Treasurer is obliged to spell out all the reasons that cause him to come to particular conclusions about anything at all. I cannot guarantee to provide an explanation. The Treasurer is still out of the country, and will be until next Monday, I think. If time permits I will ask the Treasurer if he cares to make a statement on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —In his closing words I think the Minister for Finance may have just saved the day by saying that he will ask the Treasurer to make a statement or provide him with a statement which he can provide to this chamber.
—I do not mean a formal statement in the House of Representatives.

—I understand that. So that the Minister may, in a cooler frame of mind, reflect upon the position he has just put to the chamber, I simply want to say that the present position is quite unacceptable. If the Government is to legislate-and, after all, that is what it is doing in this provision of the Bill-to provide that gifts to this particular fund, the Australian Ireland Fund, should be deductable for taxpayers who make those gifts, that is a matter of interest to many people. In terms of magnitude, however, it is negligible-I think the estimate is $50,000 per annum. Nevertheless, it is a matter involving cost to the revenue, a matter on which I would have expected Senator Walsh in particular to express a keen interest and to regard as a matter of public interest.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the Minister that, as a matter of public interest, it is entirely appropriate that the Government of the day and the responsible Minister, the Treasurer, should provide an explanation. I do not expect Senator Walsh to be able to answer this question, and that is why I think it is appropriate to give him until next week, since we are coming back to the Bill. I do not necessarily expect the advisers in the box beside him to know the answer either because they may not be the right people from the right areas of the bureaucracy to know. They may not have been privy to the Treasurer's Cabinet submission. But there must have been a reason in the submission the Treasurer put to his Cabinet colleagues. He did not just put in a submission saying, `I propose that we render this fund tax deductable'. Unless things have changed very much from procedures that I seem to recall only a few years ago, he must have given some reasons to his own colleagues for proposing what is in a sense a raid-I do not want to overstate that word-on the revenue. Of course there must be a reason and it is appropriate that that reason be stated.

When we come back to debate this matter next week I trust that the Minister, having had time to reflect upon the matter a little more judiciously than his previous reactions might indicate, will provide that explanation. Having said that, I now say, on behalf of the Opposition, that we will be quite prepared to postpone further discussion on this point until we come back to the Bill as a whole in Committee next week.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) stand as printed.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. It was agreed to earlier, on Senator Tate's motion, that we would at this stage report progress.
—I was just going to move that. Has it already been done?
—There is no such motion before the Chair.
—The Minister can move it.
—Order! Senator Watson has a query on this. I call Senator Watson.

—I support Senator Walsh's thrust to establish priorities. I use the opportunity afforded by changes to the schedule of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) before us to establish a linkage with the question that I wish to put to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh). Given the complexity and difficulty that the Government had in drafting the amendment to the tax laws superannuation package to accommodate the interests of the Australian Democrats, will the Government lay those amendments on the table of the Senate this day so that the Senate can verify the accuracy, scope and effect on superannuants, or is it the intention of the Government to present the amendments immediately before the debate recommences at the committee stage next Tuesday?

—I do not know what that has to do with this Bill. I am not sure whether the amendments have been finalised. We had intended to proceed with the legislation last night if the amendments were ready and if there had been an agreement to negative the adjournment question. Since there was no agreement to negative the adjournment question, we decided to leave it until next week. I do not know whether the amendments are finished. Of course, it relates not only to a different Bill from the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) but also to a completely different package of Bills from this package. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is away; I will contact his office.
—I would like to pursue this matter.
—You understand, Senator Watson, that your remarks have to be relevant to the Bill.

—They will be relevant under subparagraph 221yda. Could the Minister give an assurance to the Committee that we have at least 24 hours notice so that we can consider the amendment package, given its complexity and the wide effect that it will have on the superannuation industry? If the Government has had difficulty in drafting the amendments, surely the Opposition will be given a reasonable time to look at them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.
