—It may be that this question will be better answered by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.
—I think I can assist Senator Jones.

—This is a genuine question without notice; honourable senators should not knock it. I am aware of the problem to which Senator Jones refers, regarding the ACF document and concerns about it by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Certainly, that document contains a number of statements with which I am not entirely in agreement. Clearly, the statement on asthma sprays is one with which I have already expressed disagreement in this chamber. Honourable senators may recall that, when we debated the ozone depleting substances legislation some time ago, I specifically referred to the fact that the Government would exempt from the provisions of that Bill asthma sprays and sprays for medical use. There has never been a point of disagreement between the Opposition and the Government on that point.
—Hear, hear!

—Given that some of us use them, that makes it even more likely that we will stick together on this issue. The National Health and Medical Research Council was quite correct to raise its concerns. There is no doubt that the ACF document could lead some children to believe that, in order to do their bit to protect the environment, they should avoid the use of their inhalers, the most common one being ventolin. If that were to occur, their medical conditions could worsen. It is worth noting that the ACF's publication has now been altered and that sentence deleted. The ACF is sending out a revised text which I think overcomes the problem. Obviously, it regrets any inconvenience that the original publication may have caused.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's little homily delivered in Bendigo on Wednesday when he suggested that Australians suffering from his bungled economic policies should use their yet to be received tax cuts to offset the burden of record interest rates, spend some and save the rest. Apart from the fact that for hundreds of thousands of--
—What should they do with their money?
—He said that they should spend some and save the rest.
—Who said that?

—The Prime Minister said that in Bendigo on Wednesday. Apart from the fact that for hundreds of thousands of people there simply will not be anything left, does he agree that there is little incentive for saving when the combination of taxation and inflation often leaves savers worse off? What action does the Minister plan to take to prioritise his publicly expressed support for the need to consider some concessions for savers?

—First of all, I am sure the Prime Minister said nothing about suffering from bungled economic policies. If Senator Crichton-Browne included that as part of a quotation, it is wrong. I did see the transcript of what the Prime Minister said in Bendigo and I thought it was excellent advice. It is impeccable advice. It is the sort of advice that has been given down the ages by people of prudent mind. In so far as savings are concerned, Senator Crichton-Brown, with his profound interest in macro-economic policy, will of course be aware that the aggregate level of savings in Australia at present is the most important issue. Whether they be public savings or private savings is not of great relevance to the macro-economic problems. Nonetheless, I imagine there are insufficient incentives in some areas of the private sector for individuals to save. The Prime Minister has said that this matter is undoubtedly being discussed publicly not only in the community but also by economic commentators. It is a matter on which work is being done by people in the financial community, academics and governments. I can take the answer no further than that at this stage.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. On the figures provided by the Government, the tax break for a married man on a single income and with two children will be valued at $25.65. If he has a mortgage of $40,000, the difference arising from the interest rate variation between 13 1/2 per cent and 17 per cent is $25.15. What does the Minister recommend that that person do with his 50c savings?

—I do not regard it as my prerogative to make a recommendation to that hypothetical person. Senator Crichton-Browne should well know that the people in that circumstance are comparatively not enormous in number--
—People who earn $25,000 a year and have two children and one income?

—That is right, and who pay a mortgage at that level. The other point I make to Senator Crichton-Browne is that most people in the Parliament and elsewhere are concerned at the high level of interest rates; nobody wants that. The point is that in the current economic circumstances we cannot have an immediate reduction of interest rates. As soon as we can, we will.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a statement by the Queensland Minister for Mines, Energy and Northern Development, Mr Tenni, describing the Queensland royalty on proceeds from gold mining as `the people's reasonable return' on minerals ownership and contrasting that royalty with what he described as a gold tax imposed by the Commonwealth? Can the Minister inform the Senate what the practical difference is between the tax referred to and the Queensland royalty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I read in the `The Nation' column of yesterday's Australian Financial Review that the Queensland Minister for Mines, Energy and Northern Development had said that I was wrong when I described the Queensland State tax on goldmining production or profit as a tax. He said that it is not a tax, it is a royalty, and that I do not understand the difference between a tax and a royalty. He has raised a fascinating matter and a fascinating insight into the minds of members of the National Party of Australia and indeed, into the minds of members of the Opposition. I recall that recently Senator Chaney made a speech to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association in which he distinguished himself by saying something like, `The Opposition would remove secondary taxation in favour of the introduction of a royalty system'. It seems that if one asks the question, `When is a tax not a tax?', members of the Opposition will say, `When you call it a royalty'. Then they can pretend that they are not taxing anyone.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to make the position clear, let me state the following facts: the Commonwealth proposes to extend ordinary company taxation to gold mining companies which have been exempt from company tax. It is proposing to do that in 1991. The Queensland Government imposes a royalty on gold mining activity in Queensland, as does every State and Territory in Australia, with the exception of Victoria and Western Australia, and that is in the form of a secondary tax. The Queensland tax taxes what is the highest return-a tax on production or a tax on the profit of the company. To describe it as not being a tax would be interesting to gold mining companies, because the effect when they write out their cheques to pay the State Treasury is the same as paying a tax.

In order to define this matter I have looked at a couple of elementary references. I have before me the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Dictionary of Modern Economics, in which it says under the heading `Royalty':
This is a tax paid to the UK Government-
the reference is the United Kingdom-
by organisations exploiting minerals as all mineral rights are vested in the Crown.

It goes on to refer to a royalty as being a tax in that sense. I have another reference here in the Handbook of Public Economics, Volume 1, which is edited by two people, one from Harvard University and one from the University of Pennsylvania. On the subject of taxes they say, after a description:
These taxes include severance taxes based on output or gross revenue, sometimes called royalties, net profit taxes, licence fees and property taxes.

The truth is that taxes come in all forms, but they all belong to the generic bracket `tax'. Whether we call it a royalty or not does not mean to say that it is not a tax. In the case of Queensland, I have to say that Mr Martin Tenni should go back to his basic economics text and try to not confuse Queenslanders that a royalty is not a tax-it is. The impact on the gold mining industry is that of a tax. If Mr Tenni is calling on the Commonwealth Government not to extend company tax to gold mining companies-something that all other companies in Australia have to pay-and he thinks that is an inhibition on exploration, he ought to do something about his own tax. I am not counselling him to do that, but if he objects to the level of taxation, he has it within his power to reduce it.

In conclusion, one of my objections to what the Queensland Government does is that it does not open itself or its accounts to public scrutiny. We do not know how much it collects from Queensland gold mining companies. We wish that an open and transparent operation existed in Queensland, as it ought to exist in all democracies, so that people could see from whence the taxes are exacted and how much is exacted. If Queensland conformed to that basic norm, we would know what the industry does pay.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Government satisfied that those Chinese students studying in Australia who are sponsored and financed by the Chinese Government are presently receiving adequate funds to pay for food and shelter, especially those students who have been actively engaged in pro-democracy activities in recent weeks? If not, will the Government take steps to help these students financially? Will the Government cancel overseas student charges for Chinese students obliged to stay in Australia due to the present situation in China? What amount and type of aid is Australia sending to China in the present crisis?

—I have an answer to most of the question. There are very few students from the People's Republic of China (PRC) studying in Australia who are supported financially by the Chinese Government. I think there are something like 10,000 in total, but very few are supported financially by the Chinese Government. There has been no indication to date that the PRC Government has withdrawn financial assistance from those students that it has been supporting. However, the Government is sensitive to the problems faced by PRC students in Australia as a result of the events in Beijing. Should any students who were previously sponsored by the Chinese Government find themselves in financial difficulties, the Government will consider those students' positions sympathetically on a case by case basis. As to the amount and type of aid Australia is currently sending to China, I am afraid I do not have the answer. I could probably supply the answer in writing next week if the honourable senator wishes.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister have a figure for the number of people in the category of students funded directly by the PRC? Will the Government consider-as I asked-cancelling overseas student charges for Chinese students who are obliged to stay in Australia due to the present situation in China?

—We do not have a precise figure on the number of Government sponsored Chinese students. That information is certainly not available on such short notice. I might be able to get a figure later. The total number of students from the People's Republic of China is, I think, about 10,000. I do not see any particular reason, prima facie, why the Government should consider suspending charges for those who were not sponsored by the Government of China or, for that matter, those who are sponsored by the Chinese Government and on behalf of whom that Government was paying fees as long as that Government continues to pay them.

—Has the Minister for Consumer Affairs seen reports that have been critical of the Government's plans to regulate the credit reference area? Do those reports carry justifiable criticisms of the Government's plans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen such reports. I have also seen an overwhelming number of reports indicating support for the Government's plans in this area. These reports come not only from a wide range of commentators, community groups and members of the community, but also from members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, and even, this week, one conveying in-principle support for legislation to cover this area from one of the executive officers of the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd, Mr Andrew Woods. The reports that are critical have been based on an overreaction-something of a kneejerk response-and on a lack of objective assessment of what the Government is basically doing here. It should also be stated that the reports are based also on a lack of real appreciation of both the community's and this Parliament's concern for privacy.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of points arise from the reports. The first is the need for legislation. It is clear that not only has there been community concern over a period about the need for legislation in this area-instanced also by an editorial in the Melbourne Age this week which said basically things to that effect-but also a joint select committee of this Parliament, in its consideration of the Australia Card, made much of the point that this particular area is one that governments should address in the short term. As I said, even the organisation involved pivotally in this area, the Credit Reference Association of Australia, is on record, together with other leaders of industry, saying that the legislation is essential.

A second point that has been made is that the Government is being coerced into a rushed decision. As I said, the matter has been under consideration for quite some time by members of both sides of the Parliament. It has been considered basically because of the fact that the current system to protect individuals and their privacy as well as the whole system has not worked. A report from the New South Wales Privacy Committee in 1983 concluded:
The kinds of credit reporting problems encountered by consumers are serious and persistent. The protection offered by the Agreement is piecemeal and unreliable.
The agreement it refers to there is a self-regulatory agreement which was in place in New South Wales. The report went on to state:

Most notably the Agreement has failed as an example of self-regulation. Whether through ignorance, conscious determination, or lack of awareness of the Agreement's importance, credit grantors in large numbers are failing to comply with its terms.
It is fair to say that there has been quite a degree of community and parliamentary discussion about the need for action.

The third point that needs to be addressed is that the Government is not concerned only with privacy matters. There are privacy concerns relating to this particular issue. There are 4,500 members with almost 24,000 access points to a whole range of private information. This must be of concern to the Government, particularly when there is potential and actual damage to individuals by inaccuracy or unauthorised use of information. The point also needs to be made that there are substantial practical problems with one of the major concerns that have been expressed-the stopping of positive reporting. The basic practical concern is that the submission which has been put to Government means that only a small closed user group of credit providers would be able to have access to any expanded information on data bases. Of course, that would give competitive advantage to that particular group and it would also mean a need to amend the Trade Practices Act to accommodate this particular proposal. Also, there are particular practical problems with bank indemnities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; five minutes.
—I have only gone for three and I have two more to go. We are discussing a very important matter.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. This is typical of the attitude of a number of Ministers in this place. You heard the Minister's reply, Mr President, `I have only gone for three minutes; I have two to go'. Clearly he has a prepared statement to give. If he wants to make a statement he should do so after Question Time. The Opposition has been extremely patient about this over a long period and, quite frankly, it has run out of patience.
—There is no point of order, but I would remind Senator Bolkus that it has been a very long answer.

—There are other points which need to be made. In this area the Government is concerned to cooperate with industry to obtain a final result. We have made that clear from the start. We will do that in respect of the development of the code of conduct which will govern the fine tuning of this particular proposal. We will also do that before that code of conduct has to be developed. Having made these three or four points, I specifically suggest to those in industry who are concerned about this, that the best way to approach this problem is to have constructive, direct discussions with the Government. Such discussions would be productive. The organisation of a coterie, as has occurred in the last few days, would not be productive. We think that the most beneficial outcome for all-for industry, the community, government and the privacy of the individual-will occur if that direct, constructive negotiation continues. It is important, not only because of the development of the code of conduct which will fine tune the area, but also because there is a certain degree of misinformation about what we are doing.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the labour force statistics produced yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Has the Government considered the implications of the main components of that release-in other words, the very substantial rise in female employment together with the substantial rise in the number of females looking for work? Has the Minister noted that, according to the document, the people who are suffering the greatest burden of unemployment in Australia today are young girls of 15 to 20 years of age? Has the Minister considered the possibility that the mothers of these girls are being forced out to work by the high mortgage interest rates and the policies of this Government, thus taking the jobs which could be obtained by their daughters? What has happened to the Government's Priority One: Young Australia program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has been asking questions very diligently for a number of years about the levels of unemployment amongst young people. I think he would concede that there has been a marked improvement in the figures for unemployed young people. In fact, they are now broadly consistent--
—Because they are being kept in school.

—Senator Harradine interjects, `Because they are being kept in school'. That is not a very positive contribution to the debate. I suppose he would say they should be working in shops. I think the honourable senator would concede that in the last few years there has been a marked improvement in respect of the unemployment rate for young people. As I recall it, the unemployment rate for young people is now broadly consistent throughout Australia with the unemployment rate for adults, whereas the difference between the two some years ago-when this Government came into office-was 15 per cent.
—That is not right. It is about 10 per cent higher. Read the figures.
—I am not relying exclusively on my memory in this respect. The point is that there has been a great narrowing of the gap between unemployed young people and unemployed adults and that is true.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point I want to make relates to Senator Harradine's suggestion that high interest rates are forcing women to work in order to help pay their mortgages, and this is detrimental to the employment of young girls. Not having made the analysis, I am unable to comment on that claim in any great detail. However, I suspect that it does not stand up. First of all, I point out to the honourable senator that the female participation rate, although the highest recorded in these recently released figures, has been growing very strongly since 1983. That growth is largely reflected in expansion in those areas of the economy where women are largely employed, particularly the service sector. This is confirmed by the fact that at a time of strong growth in female employment, the unemployment rate for males has fallen from 10.3 per cent in May 1983 to 7 per cent in May 1989. I think it is unlikely that women's participation in the work force is expanding at the expense of the male participation because of the growth in service sector employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the junior females?

—In so far as the higher level of junior female unemployment is concerned, I will obtain the figures for the honourable senator and provide him with an answer on that point. I was concerned to deal with the honourable senator's assumption that somehow there was a finite pool of female employment and that at a time of high interest rates married women were returning to work and squeezing young females out of the labour market. On the basis of the figures released yesterday, I think there is little evidence to support that analysis.

—by leave-I am taking the unusual step of addressing a question to Senator Giles in her capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to an article in the West Australian of 5 June 1989 quoting Senator Knowles as supporting the use of the drug ethylene diamine tetra acetate, which I think is much better referred to as EDTA. Does the Government agree with Senator Knowles's promotion of the use of this drug for chelation therapy? Further, what is the Government's attitude to the use of this drug?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. This raises a very important question for politicians and, indeed, journalists because it would appear, on the basis of anecdotal evidence, that assertions are made about what the properties of drugs for treatment of serious medical illness are. There is always a fine line between publicly espousing those views and privately lobbying them within the Government. I do not hold Senator Knowles at all responsible for the way in which she is reported. That would be wrong, and indeed the reporting in the article is highly coloured. It is headed `A Plea from the Heart'; it then reports, `Patients want drug embargo relaxed'; and it is then subheaded, `Ailing Perth patients are lobbying the Federal Government to free up supplies of a miracle drug that supposedly cures heart attack victims'. That is journalese of the worst sort and I think it sets up anxiety in people with serious medical illness about the possibility of a miracle cure which may or may not be true. I think therefore that one ought to be very cautious in making assertions about the properties of specific drugs.

ANSWER.PARA: Ethylene diamine tetra acetate, or EDTA, is chemically a chelating agent. It has some legitimate uses in medicine, including as a preservative.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't even know how to pronounce it.
—Order! Continue Senator Cook.

—Another use is as treatment for some heavy metal poisonings. The Department of Community Services and Health permits its importation for these purposes. For a number of years it has been promoted by various doctors and others as chelation therapy, which is claimed to reverse the formation of atheroma or fatty plaques in artery walls. But the problem is that in 1983 the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee considered the use of chelation therapy and recommended against it. This view was endorsed by the National Health and Medical Research Council and by the National Heart Foundation. I am advised, as well, that the United States Food and Drug Administration does not approve of this `useful' therapy.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department can approve EDTA for use in chelation therapy only if a sponsor submits data which establishes the substance's quality, safety and efficacy for this purpose; that is to say, there has to be proper trialling by scientific method to establish whether or not the properties that are alleged to exist are in fact scientifically proven to exist against the standards we require. It is up to the sponsors of those drugs to take that action. If they do not take that action for the proper trialling, I do not make a judgment as to whether that proves or disproves the matter, but I just note for the record that they do not take that action and it is for them to decide whether or not they should. Claims which imply that EDTA has been administered in Western Australia in recent years without adverse affects cannot be accepted by the Department. We are not aware of any adequate, systematic gathering of information which would allow ascertainment of the fates of the treated patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is Australia the only place in the world which does not allow it?

—If such information exists, it should be submitted to the Department as part of an application to market EDTA for this purpose. If Senator Knowles has this information or knows where it can be obtained, I invite her to submit it to the proper authorities.
—I have given it to the Minister.
—Order, Senator Knowles!

—I conclude, in the face of the interjections, that it is entirely wrong, and indeed it has a fiendish effect upon patients who are ill, if allegations are made that a miracle drug exists which can cure them in such a way as to raise hopes and expectations which scientifically may not be real. There has to be proper scientific assessment of these things before those sorts of allegations are spun off.

—I have been asked a question about it and I will give an answer. There has been some highly innovative research in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation over the past few years, opening up the first real prospects of developing a flu vaccine. A team led by Dr Peter Colman has worked on the vaccine proposal. The Minister for Social Security has received a number of representations on this matter, including from the Member for Denison, Duncan Kerr, MP.

The first is an investigation of technical options for computer centres, including the costs of each option associated with sites, hardware, software, maintenance etc. The second will assess the likely impact of each option on staffing and service quality and the participation of staff associations has been sought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Newman asked me a question about a Mr Hickman who was formerly employed as a Senior Private Secretary by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I undertook to obtain an early answer. First, Mr Hickman was employed as a Senior Private Secretary by the Minister for Defence until October 1988. Secondly, Arvin Consultancy Pty Ltd, of which Mr Hickman is Managing Director, is registered as a lobbyist for the Transfield group, of which Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) is a member. AMECON is one of two consortia competing for the Anzac ship project.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the third part of the question is no. At the time Mr Hickman left the Minister's office, no deliverables under the design development contract or the request for tender had been provided to the Department of Defence. It might be noted that detailed tender documentation of this kind has not been provided to the Minister for Defence or his office. Public Service procedures require Commonwealth officers in sensitive positions to seek assent before taking up outside employment. These procedures do not have application to ministerial staff. However, in Mr Hickman's case the general principles applied to public servants appear to have been followed. An officer is required to declare his interest in outside employment as soon as the possibility of employment which could give rise to an actual or apparent conflict of interest arises.

He has had no preferential access to the Minister's office or the Department since leaving the Minister's office. Ministerial staff, unlike Service officers and public servants working in the Department of Defence, do not participate in commercial activities such as design specification and tender evaluation which could give rise to a conflict of interest.

I do not have the precise terms of Senator Newman's question before me, but the answer to the fourth part of it is that there is nothing improper in what has occurred. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Michael Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on homebuyers, small businesses and farmers.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If anything can be relatively important after the moving memorial ceremony we have just completed in the Great Hall for the thousands of Chinese martyrs to democracy, then this is such an important issue. Before I deal with it I thank you, Mr President-I am certain on behalf of all senators-as one of the Presiding Officers, for giving approval for the ceremony to take place. The ceremony was attended by almost every senator and a capacity audience of mourners for the disaster that has taken place in China.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government, due to the collapse of its economic policies, has placed an excessive reliance on huge and rising interest rates to control the economy. This has resulted in an unfair concentration of the burden of reduced living standards on small businesses and farmers, both of whom have had to put up with interest rate rises of up to 50 per cent over the last year or so, and Australian families trying to pay off their own homes, who have had an increase in repayments on average mortgages of about $56 a week this financial year, or about three times the size of next month's tax cuts for an average worker and double the promised wage rise. We have a looming disaster for those people. Only a particular group of people in Australia is being called on to carry the whole burden of this Government's economic policy, as the whole burden of this Government's policy is directed at interest rates.

Not all Australians are suffering anything like the same burden from this policy. It is a very selective, discriminatory and disastrous policy which is aimed at those very sections of the community which Australia needs for its economic recovery or the maintenance of family life. It is young families who are hardest hit by mortgage interest rates.

Let us examine what is really happening to mortgage interest rates. In June and July of last year mortgage interest rates were 13.5 per cent. They are now 17 per cent and it is expected that they will go to 18 per cent. Mortgage rate increases for small businesses are between 4 and 6 per cent and similar increases have taken place for higher overdrafts. That affects those people in Australia who are borrowers and who are endeavouring to do what they can to stimulate this economy and house their families.

What does the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tell us about the future? Just as he told us before the Western Australian election that there would be no rise in interest rates-and they have since gone up 2 per cent-once again he is saying the same sort of reckless nonsense. This morning, on the AM program, Mr Hawke was questioned on interest rates and is reported as saying:

I don't believe there's any need for them to go any higher. I think with the tightness of monetary policy and wages policy and budget policy, it ought to be enough to slow the economy down, and I hope it will.
Mr Peter Thompson then asked Mr Andrew Gilkes, the financial markets economist with Westpac Banking Corporation:
Well, those people holding mortgages are most concerned, naturally, with the mortgage interest rate-now at a record 17 per cent. Is it going to go higher?
Andrew Gilkes replied:

Well, I think, to be realistic, all the pressures are still probably upwards on interest rates. The best we could hope for, I think, is interest rates don't go any higher over the next six months. I think there's very little chance they'll be coming down, but still the risk is that they may need to move higher.
Peter Thompson said:
So they are going to stay at least at 17, and may still go to 17.5 or 18?
Mr Gilkes replied:
Looking at the economic evidence to date, I mean, that's the only realistic conclusion we could draw.

It is interesting that the only realistic conclusion that one can draw, if one is actually in this market and if one knows what is going on, is exactly the contrary to the conclusion asserted by this Prime Minister, who has misled this nation consistently about the direction of interest rates. It is exactly the opposite to what the Prime Minister has said, because the Prime Minister has established an unbeatable record of deliberately setting out to mislead this nation on the matter of interest rates.
Mr Geoff Kitney, in his column in today's Australian Financial Review, says that the interest rate problem is causing real problems within the Government. He states:

Monetary policy tightening, intended to slow business investment and reduce consumption, has pushed home mortgage rates to record levels and is taking a savage toll on young home buyers. But it still appears not to have achieved the Government's objectives.
Of course, that is the central issue. Mr Kitney goes on:
But reliance on monetary policy is increasingly being seen as economically inadequate as well as politically damaging.

It is that damage-not simply political but also personal and economic-that we wish to deal with in this matter of public importance. The collapse of the Government's economic policy, which the Opposition warned of for years but specifically after the last Budget when we announced the extent to which we believed that the Budget was wrong-and we have been proved totally right-will be dealt with by Senator Stone when he speaks on this matter subsequently. Senator Hill will deal with the consequences for Australian families, the hardships they are facing as a result of this failed economic policy, and the Government's concentration on the cruellest possible approach rather than a fair and equitable approach.

I wish to concentrate most heavily on housing, which is clearly the biggest area where interest rates impact directly on ordinary Australian families trying to pay off their homes. One of the most depressing things is that high interest rates, and the increases that have taken place so far this financial year, have helped to increase the Government's tax revenues. Perhaps this Government feels that it has a vested interest in increasing interest rates for those people trying to pay off their own homes. Trading bank loans, or assets directly affected by the huge interest rate rises, appear to total about $150 billion. Higher interest rates mean a rise in taxable earnings on those deposits that have flowed into the loans, totalling about $6 billion or so a year, of which about $2.4 billion would probably go in extra tax one way or another. On savings bank and other home lending, totalling about $60 billion, about $20 billion is at fixed interest rates, and $40 billion would be subject to the huge rises forced by this Government on home mortgages. This would mean about an extra $1.4 billion a year in interest being charged, of which something like $500m will go to the Hawke Government in extra income tax. The Hawke Government is ripping something like $500m a year out of home buyers' mortgage interest repayments because of the huge rise in interest rates. I hope that people who are having to pay these enormous rises are well aware of that.

On top of that, there are all the other non-bank financial intermediaries, who have about $100 billion of assets out there on which high interest rates are being paid. These may well not be capable of being added on to the amount I have outlined. Some of it may be loans between these various financial intermediaries. But the simple fact is that this Government has a vested interest in high interest rates because of the massive increase in taxation that takes place on those higher interest rates, paid for in particular by Australian families struggling to meet their mortgage payments.

However, to a large extent, Australian families have been protected from the full cruelty of this Government's high interest rate policy. They are being protected by the actions of the banks and building societies themselves, to the extent that those actions have frustrated the Government's economic policy. They have not passed on the immediate impact on people's pockets of this high interest rate. What the banks and building societies have done in many instances is simply to extend the term of the loan rather than to increase the monthly repayment amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —That means that person will never own his own home.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne has said, this means that that person will never own his own home. This simply lengthens the loan to infinity. It is a reality that people must face as sooner or later they will be called on to pay this bill which is hidden from them by the banks and building societies at the moment. These people will end up with a huge future bill unless interest rates come down quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than pick someone else's situation I would like to let the Senate know how this really affects people in this situation and I am one in this situation. I have no embarrassment at all about revealing the extent to which this Government's policies has affected me. When one talks about interest rate matters in the Senate one should be prepared to admit that one is affected by them. To that extent I have to disclose an interest. I am concerned for my own benefit about the huge interest rate rise. There are very few Australians who are not affected because they are trying to pay off their own home, trying to run a farm, trying to run a small business.

Let us look at what it means to someone who borrows money. I borrowed $125,000 to buy a Canberra townhouse at the beginning of last year. My monthly repayments were $1,480, which covered the interest cost of $1,400-odd, and I have paid close to $1,000 off the principal of the loan. But last month the interest bill alone had risen as a direct result of this Government's determined and deliberate policies to $1,665 a month, which is $185 a month more than my repayments of $1,480. The bank had very kindly said to me, `Yes, we're increasing interest rates but don't worry you don't have to increase your monthly repayments'. This month the latest one per cent rise to 17 per cent will lift the interest bill alone to $1,765. Every month I will go further and further into debt so that after I have paid almost $18,000 a year in mortgage repayments I will owe an extra $3,400 on my Canberra house.

I am not feeling the pain of Hawke's high interest rates now but I certainly will in the future. That goes for most Australian home owners. One of the problems is that banks and building societies have not drawn that money out of the community and will let people like me suffer in the future rather than in the present. It means that monetary policy has not worked. It means that consumer demand has not been reduced and, to an extent, by being kind to its customers the banks and building societies have frustrated the Government's economic policies. In other words this Government has wanted the people of Australia to suffer a darn sight more than they have so far. This Government has wanted the banks and the building societies to take that extra money out.

No doubt the Reserve Bank of Australia will bring pressure to bear on the banks and building societies, particularly after the $5 billion so-called tax cuts take place next month. No doubt the Reserve Bank will be suggesting to the banks and the building societies that they should increase the monthly repayments because otherwise this Government's monetary policy, the only economic policy it has going for it, is being effectively frustrated. That is why it is such nonsense for so many people who do not understand what is happening in this world to take their criticism to the banks and say that it is the fault of the banks that there are high interest rates and that all of these problems are taking place. The banks have no option but to increase interest rates. Apart from anything else, it is impossible for them to try to offer lower interest rates when they have to compete against this Government itself in the marketplace for money. If the Government is offering an interest rate of 17.4 per cent-which it is on treasury notes, I think, at the moment-how can the banks possibly expect to be able to borrow money at a much lower rate and still lend it out at anything less than 17 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, as interest rates go up, the value of your home goes down because there is less demand.

—Quite properly, these higher interest rates are pushing down the values of the homes people have just bought and their equity in them because they will owe more and more on houses that are going to be worth less and less as a direct result of this Government's policies. The only people who are fully affected by this so far are new home seekers. As I said, existing home owners largely are being protected by the actions of the banks and building societies but I expect that their own cash flow needs will force them sooner or later to increase these repayments. Then the people of Australia will suffer much more severely than they are now and will know who to blame-the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: But there are some people who are being totally hit by these new home interest rates. They are the home seekers, people who have wanted to get a home for themselves, who have the right-or had the right under previous governments-to expect, if they have an average income, that they can afford to buy their own homes. They cannot under this Government, and there is no prospect that they will under this Government.

Let us have a look at the position in respect of an average mortgage. The only people who can afford an average mortgage cost-which is getting up around $300 a week-are those earning about $1,200 a week. People need to earn $60,000 a year to be able to afford the average New South Wales mortgage of about $84,000-and a mortgage of $84,000 will not buy much in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rich get richer and the poor get poorer.

—The poor certainly will get poorer. Here is the dreadful, appalling reality: Australians earning less than $60,000 a year cannot afford just the average mortgage. This Government expects people to take that calmly and happily. We are facing an absolute disaster for home seekers in Australia. I imagine that when the banks eventually are forced, either by the moral suasion of the Reserve Bank or by deliberate Government policy, to increase the amount of repayments for existing home buyers the extent of that disaster will spread to existing home owners who are paying off their own homes. It seems to me that this Government is probably considering an early election between its ephemeral tax hand-out in July and when the banks will be forced to increase their repayments.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government's interest rate policy has been a disaster so far but it is going to be an even greater disaster as time goes by. If all we have to rely on are the promises of the Prime Minister that interest rates will not go up, we face an absolute disaster.
