SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance which has been raised by Senator Michael Baume and which claims disastrous impacts of interest rates on home buyers, small business and farmers. I would like to remind Senator Baume about a few facts in debating this proposition here this afternoon. Under the coalition Government six years ago 105,000 new dwellings were commenced in Australia. This year, under a Labor Government, a forecast 168,000 dwellings will be started. In terms of real bricks and mortar activity there will be a 60 per cent increase this financial year in the number of dwelling starts in Australia compared with the number when the Opposition was last in power in this country. In the past 12 months private investment in dwellings has grown by 20 per cent, but six years ago under the Liberals dwelling investment fell by a massive 22 per cent. The national income figures are on the record and Senator Baume should know about them. After all, in 1982-83, when only 105,000 dwellings were started and when there was a massive 22 per cent reduction in new dwelling investment in Australia, Senator Baume, who has brought on this matter of public importance this afternoon, was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer in the Liberal Government. He should know those figures as he had access to the data. This matter of public importance is exposed as an exercise in hypocrisy. The Liberals assume that the public has a short memory. That is the way they operate; that is the way conservative politicians in this country do business.

SPEECH.PARA: The tenor of Senator Baume's matter of public importance was interest rates allegedly hitting small business. According to the economic textbooks one barometer of interest rate activity in the business sector surely is the level of investment activity. Let us look at investment reality and the figures for the gross domestic product to March this year. The facts about investment in Australia are in black and white for all to see. These are results never achieved by the Liberals in government. In the 12 months to March this year the gross domestic product figures which relate to new investment activity in plant and equipment show a whopping increase of 25.2 per cent. In one financial year investment in plant and equipment by the business sector of the Australian economy has grown by over one-quarter, and that is growth ahead of the increase in costs. It is a real growth of 25 per cent in one financial year.

In bringing on this matter of public importance this afternoon, is Senator Baume claiming that none of this investment is by small business? Is he suggesting that perhaps corporate investment is rising but investment by small business is falling? Of course, he cannot argue that proposition. The increase in new business activity in plant and equipment of 25 per cent this financial year surely must be occurring in small business just as it is in the corporate sector. Is Senator Baume also suggesting that the farming sector-he referred explicitly to farmers-is not boosting its investment activity? As I have pointed out, overall this financial year plant and equipment investment has increased by a massive 25 per cent and that must have been contributed to by a range of business sectors. The farming sector must be increasing its investment, just as the small business sector must be, to achieve an overall figure of 25 per cent growth in new plant and equipment.

I say to the Liberals, `Eat your heart out'. When in government they never achieved growth in plant and equipment investment by over one-quarter in real terms in a single financial year. I simply compare that figure with the last year that the Liberals were in power, when new investment in plant and equipment in the economy slumped by 16.1 per cent.

Senator Baume has debated interest rates this afternoon. Of course they are high. The Government is concerned for the plight of borrowers. This week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) campaigned in Ballarat and Bendigo and made it abundantly clear that he is concerned about the impact of high interest rates. But he has also said time and time again, just as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said, that interest rates will come down as soon as is economically possible. Interest rates are not an end in themselves. The Government does not want high interest rates for their own sake. The fiction that those opposite are trying to create in the community is that high interest rates are an end in themselves and that this Government wants high interest rates per se. There is a key reason for using interest rate policy-the economy is growing too fast. That is something Liberal Party members cannot come to terms with. When they were on the treasury bench they drove the economy into the ground, through the floor. Now they cannot come to terms with the fact that Australia's economy is growing faster than the Government wants it to grow.

I would like to make a contrast. When in government, the Liberals had high interest rates and an economic recession. Our problem is high interest rates and record economic growth. The economy is growing too fast. Total spending in the economy is outstripping local production. That is the heart of our problem. Gross national expenditure grew by 11.3 per cent in real terms to March this year compared with production of 5.4 per cent as measured by gross domestic product. Supplies have to come from elsewhere if local production cannot keep up with spending power. That is why there is a growth in imports, and hence the balance of payments deficit.

As a result of these pressures, this financial year the balance of payments on current account-the overseas deficit on our external transactions-might account for about 5 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, or our total national income. We have to keep these balance of payments figures in perspective. It is a matter of record that only six years ago, in 1981-82, the Liberal Party in government recorded a balance of payments on current account deficit of $9 billion-$9,000m. That deficit was equivalent to 6 per cent of gross domestic product. That was the former Government's record. At the very worst, the Government's deficit for this financial year might get to 5 per cent.

The Liberals' figure of 6 per cent of gross domestic product contributed by the current account deficit in today's economic values, in today's dollar terms, would be $19.5 billion. It is impossible. Not one person on the other side of the chamber, not one of the Liberal Party economic spokespersons, in his wildest dreams has been able to come up with a figure of $19.5 billion for this financial year.

Opposition senators have speculated about figures. We know that, for the first 10 months of the year, the figure was $14 billion. But it is mathematically impossible to go from $14 billion in the first 10 months of this financial year to the equivalent of their deficit in government of $19.5 billion by the end of this financial year. As I pointed out, the former Government's deficit was 6 per cent of gross domestic product; ours might get to 5 per cent.

One of the reasons we are resorting to interest rate policies is that the other arms of government economic policy are very tight. We have a tight incomes policy, despite rapid economic growth. We are planning to keep wage growth in the community down to 6 1/2 per cent next financial year-a remarkable figure, given the strong situation in the labour market whereby we would expect rapid growth in wages. Our fiscal policy-that is, the balance between government spending and taxing-is tight. I reiterate our record in reducing government spending as a proportion of our national income, our gross domestic product. In 1982-83, the last year of the Liberal Government, Commonwealth Government spending contributed 29 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. As a result of continued stringent fiscal policy, in this financial year Commonwealth Government spending will be 25.6 per cent of gross domestic product. We have seen a massive reduction in the share of government outlays in gross domestic product-a good measure of the stringency of fiscal policy as practised by the Federal Government. A result of that is the Budget surplus of over $5,000m this year.

I would be the first to admit that monetary policy is an imperfect weapon. It is a blunt instrument. It takes a very long time to work. It has very long time lags. When we unscrew monetary policy it takes a long time for the pressures in the Australian economy to reduce. Despite the matter of public importance brought forward this afternoon by Senator Baume, I ask what the Liberals would do in place of our policies. What would they do to cut imports? Would they slash production? After all, they did that in 1981. Would they slash employment, as they did in 1981? Would they drive the Australian economy into the ground? They are well practised at that. They did it once, and we cannot afford to let them do it again.

We are getting our economic conditions right under this Labor Government. After all, the inflation rate and the level of increases in prices are the important determinants of interest rates in the community. Let us look at the record on inflation rates. When the Liberal Party was in power the annual rate of increase in prices in the Australian economy, as measured by the consumer price index, was at double digit levels. Senator Baume knows that. As I pointed out earlier this afternoon, in 1982 and 1983 Senator Baume had access to all the secret data. He was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer in the Liberal Government. He knows what the figures were. He probably knows that absolutely everything I am saying is correct. We had 11.5 per cent inflation under the Liberals. We do not have 10 per cent inflation now, we do not have 9 per cent inflation now, we certainly do not have 8 per cent inflation now, and we do not have 7 per cent inflation now. The inflation rate is below 7 per cent. We wound back the inflationary cost forces in the Australian economy from 11.5 per cent, when Senator Baume was the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and when Senator Stone, one of the next speakers in this debate, was the head of Treasury, to below 7 per cent. They are the facts; that is the reality. That is the Liberal Party's record in government-double digit inflation matched by double digit unemployment. No wonder the people threw it out in 1983.

I would like to put on the record some further figures relating to the level of housing in Australia to give the lie to the matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Baume this afternoon. I wish to nail it right down, to show which party in government places real priority on housing. I pointed out at the beginning of my speech that in the last year the Liberals were in power 105,000 new dwellings were commenced. That is a fact. That figure comes not from this Government but from the Indicative Planning Council, an independent body which monitors the housing sector. Last year under this Labor Government many more houses than that were started, and we are looking at a figure of 168,000 for dwellings commenced in the current financial year. This is a 60 per cent rise over the record of the Liberals. Even with interest rates impacting on housing demand, of course, the figures will rise. I would be the first to admit that. But the Indicative Planning Council forecasts new dwelling commencements in the Australian community next financial year in the range of 140,000 to 144,000. These figures are one-third higher than the figure for what the Liberals did in their last year of government when they created 105,000 new residential dwellings. Next financial year, at the very worst this Government will be creating 140,000 new dwellings.

Let us have no more Liberal Party fictions and distortions about which party is the best for housing in the Australian community. The reality is that the average number of new housing starts each year under this Labor Government is 140,000. That is the reality. It is on the public record. During the life of the previous Liberal Government the average figure for new housing starts was below 130,000. Here is one simple statistic: in an average year under this Hawke Labor Government, 10,000 more new dwellings are being started in the Australian community-real bricks and mortar are being used in the Australian economy-than was the case under the previous Liberal Government.

But the Commonwealth Government does not leave it there. We are taking real action in the housing sector. For example, as a result of the housing summit held on 3 March, we are focusing on some of the key supply problems in getting affordable housing to Australian people. The Commonwealth Government is making its surplus land available for new residential allotments. The best way to fix land prices for urban development in Australia is to work on the supply side, and that is what we are doing. We have announced that over the next five years we will release surplus Commonwealth land equivalent to 27,000 new housing allotments. I am delighted to note that just two days ago the Government announced that the first 8,000 allotments will be going onto the market in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth to reduce supply constraints on the price of new residential allotments.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they would have to borrow at 17 per cent.

—Senator Stone has made another of his irrelevancies about the economy in Australia. Let us look at this Government's policy on public housing-housing for low income and needy families. In the last five years under Labor, public housing funds have increased by 20 per cent in real terms. But in five years of Liberal Government, public housing funds were cut, not increased, by 34 per cent in real terms. Under the Liberal Government, 165,000 families were housed in public housing in five years. But under Labor 215,000 families have been housed in public housing in five years. That is a very stark comparison.

SPEECH.PARA: We are entitled to ask: What exactly is the Liberal Party's housing policy? What would it do if, by some remote chance, it occupied the treasury bench in the House of Representatives? It has to announce its policies. It has to put up or shut up. Earlier this year, the previous housing spokesman for the Liberals, Mr Downer, really gave the game away in the Weekend Australian. When asked a number of categorical questions about Liberal Party policy on housing, he would not give a guarantee that a Liberal government would maintain total public housing allocations through the Federal Budget. Nor would he guarantee that Commonwealth public housing allocations, through State housing commissions, would be maintained.

When in government the Liberals showed themselves to be economically, politically and ideologically incapable of providing sufficient housing for Australians. Despite the present economic difficulties, over 160,000 new dwellings are forecast for this year under Labor-a figure that the Liberals in government could never match.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the following matter of public importance put forward by the coalition Opposition:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on homebuyers, small businesses and farmers.

There can be no doubt that high interest rates are crippling Australian home buyers, small businesses and farmers. One issue is: why has the Hawke Government botched the economy to the point at which the only arm of economic policy it is prepared to use is high interest rates? The other issue is: On what basis does the Opposition, consisting of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia, claim to be able to solve this problem? If we examine what has caused the high interest rates, we discover that both the Hawke Government and the Liberal-National coalition are in fundamental agreement on the economic policies which have created high interest rates for home buyers, small businesses and farmers. Both have supported deregulation of the financial markets, which has given ultimate control of the Australian economy to international investors, banks and financiers. Interest rates are high because some Australians are borrowing too much overseas. As a result, we now have a net debt of over $103 billion. To service this debt we must export more, sell off more Australian assets to foreign investors, borrow more, or import less.

Let us look at the option of exporting more. Although our primary producers are amongst the most efficient in the world, their produce is locked out of many markets because of the subsidisation policy of the European Community and the United States of America. Who among us can forget Vice-President Dan Quayle? Our allies prevent us from benefiting from the competitive advance of our rural producers. Our manufacturing industries have not yet shown a marked tendency to export more, despite the fact that wage costs in Australia are becoming relatively low by world standards, as Senator Maguire said, and the value of the Australian dollar has fallen since 1985.

I turn now to the option of selling off more assets to overseas investors. The increase in foreign investment in Australia has been welcomed by both the Hawke Government and the Liberal Party. With a lower currency, Australian farms, property and industry have become cheap by world standards. We are in danger of losing control of Australian industry and the economy. Yet the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal-National party coalition voted in this chamber against an Australian Democrat proposal to establish a register of foreign ownership, so that at least we would know what Australian assets were foreign owned. In debates on that matter, I have listed assets in Western Australia which have been sold to overseas interests. They include prawning operations, hotels, tourist developments and rural properties. The Australian Democrats believe that selling off Australian assets is not a viable long term policy, but that is what the Hawke Government is doing and the coalition would sell off more. They are converting our foreign debt problem into a foreign ownership problem. Future generations of Australians will be paying more in rent and dividends to the foreign owners of Australian assets. On the radio this morning I heard someone asking, `What will we do once we have sold off all the back paddocks?'. All that will be left will be the farmhouse itself.

I turn now to the option of borrowing more from overseas lenders. While most Australians know that we need to export more and import less, few Australians realise the extent to which our balance of payments problem is caused by the interest payments we must meet on past borrowings. In 1988 Australia had to pay $9.7 billion in interest on its $121 billion gross foreign debt. Writing in the Australian Financial Review of 19 May, Michael Stutchbury comments on this problem. He says:

The economy is now trapped by a vicious cycle of debt accumulation. As the foreign debt has ballooned, the interest bill has become a driving force behind the worsening current account deficit-which then adds to the foreign debt, and in turn, to the debt-servicing bill.

The bigger the debt, the bigger the risk to lend to Australia and the higher interest rates must be in order to attract foreign borrowings. So we suffer high interest rates because someone has borrowed a lot of money overseas. Who is responsible for this debt? Is it those Australians who are struggling to buy their own homes and trying to meet their mortgage interest repayments? The private sector is responsible for--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the Government's policy.

—Yes; nonetheless, the private sector is responsible for well over half of the foreign borrowings. At the end of last year, Australia's six largest corporate borrowers, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, News Corporation Ltd, the Bond Corporation, Bell Resources, Industrial Equity Ltd, and the Elders group, owed $26 billion, or over 23 per cent of our gross foreign debt. So these mates of the Liberal Party and the Labor Party get to borrow money overseas at low interest rates. They also get a tax deduction on their foreign borrowings which costs revenue billions of dollars, yet Australians, who did not borrow overseas, are expected to carry the burden of repaying that debt.

SPEECH.PARA: We face the highest interest rates in the developed economies of the world. I will give the Senate some examples. The home interest rate in the United States is 13.75 per cent and, in some cases, 10 per cent for 30 years. In Great Britain it is 13.5 per cent; France, 5 per cent to 12 per cent; Italy 13 per cent to 24 per cent; Switzerland, 6.5 per cent; Canada, 14.9 per cent; West Germany, one per cent to 7 per cent; the Netherlands, 8.5 per cent; and Ireland, 9.5 per cent. Those percentages were quoted in the Sun-Herald on 4 June 1989. If the Government denied the tax deduction to companies which borrow overseas, we would reduce our foreign debt and increase government revenue immediately. According to a Sydney Morning Herald article last year, the Qintex Group, Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd, Equitcorp Australia Ltd and the Bond Corporation all paid less than one per cent of their pre-tax profit as tax in 1988. Yet last year the Government cut the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent at a cost to revenue of almost $2 billion. The Hawke Government and the Liberal-National coalition combined yet again to vote for this measure in this chamber and the Australian Democrats opposed it.

I turn now to the topic of importing less. The Government and the Opposition argue that we are importing too much. Yet they will not consider the direct method of reducing imports. We could restrict imports through the use of quotas. We could increase taxes on selected luxury imports in order to reduce the import Bill. But the Government has chosen to reduce imports by raising interest rates to the point where many people have no money to spend on anything, including imports. I guess that is part and parcel of the whole idea. However, what is happening-and the messages coming through confirm this-is that because people do not want to lose their family home they are giving up spending on many of the basic essentials of life.

There is no doubt that families are going without food-this is happening in Western Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and, I am told, elsewhere-in order to make their mortgage repayments. This is a callous policy of squeezing home buyers, farmers and small businesses into bankruptcy so that Australia will import less. The Opposition would presumably continue this policy and/or impose new taxes such as a consumption tax to place new burdens on ordinary Australians so that the country would import less.

But the Opposition would ignore the real solution which would be to restrict imports and to take away the incentive for the biggest Australian companies to borrow overseas. In March this year, the Australian Democrats introduced into the Senate two Bills to encourage domestic savings, reduce interest rates to home buyers and provide a tax deduction on the interest payments of Australians who are living in the house they are buying. Both of the Bills were defeated by the combined vote of the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the National Party. So Australian home buyers should note the attitude of the Government and of the Opposition in relation to giving tax assistance to people who live in the homes they are buying as opposed to giving tax assistance to property investors and foreign borrowers. Such are their priorities. Negative gearing applies if one is buying a house as an investment proposition, but there is no relief at all if one is buying a house to live in it. Yet, if we can believe the Sun-Herald of Sunday, 4 June, the Opposition has discovered the issue and Mr Peacock has said it will no doubt become an election issue. I quote:
Opposition leader Andrew Peacock made it clear last night he would use housing as the key weapon in his attempt to topple the Hawke Government.
Not to ease the load on home buyers, but to `topple the Hawke Government'. The quote continues:

In his first major speech since taking over the leadership from John Howard, Mr Peacock said a coalition Government would restore home ownership as an achievable and affordable right for every Australian.

That sounds great, but if that is the case why can we not learn what those policies are right now? If they are policies which will help ordinary Australian home buyers to make those mortgage interest repayments and not be turned out of their own homes, then I can assure the Opposition that the Democrats will support such proposals. Home buyers are still being threatened with even higher interest rates. We see no sympathy at all-or very little sympathy-from the Australian banks.
We see no sympathy at all from National Australia Bank boss, Nobby Clark, who, as reported in the Perth Sunday Times on 28 May 1989, stated:
. . . If the mortgage belt doesn't want to be the ball, they can get out of the game-that is the option they have.
When talking about bankers, Mr Clark said:
. . . Of course we're bastards, didn't you know?
Further on he said:
You can be a good guy or a bad guy but the pain is the same. My view is simply, for God's sake get it out of the way. Put interest rates up as high as they have to go to stop all the bloody demand.

There is a lot of sympathy there! After all, the mortgage interest rates in New Zealand reached 23 per cent before the economy was sufficiently restrained. Farmers and small businesses are also suffering high interest rates, with threats of further increase. Some rural producers, who are regarded as high risk, are paying interest rates of 25 per cent. Small businesses are paying around 20 per cent. Of course, many small business people are paying these high interest rates on their businesses as well as paying high home mortgage interest rates. As we know, at the moment home buyers, for the most part, are paying around 17 per cent. Yet Australia's biggest corporations borrow overseas for less than 10 per cent and get a tax deduction on top of that. Until we have a government that is prepared to address this problem, the interests of farmers, small business and home buyers will continue to be sacrificed to the interest of Australia's biggest companies, the banks, foreign investors and international financing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance which has been put forward by my colleague Senator Michael Baume and which relates to the disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on home buyers, small businesses and farmers. Senator Baume, in his earlier remarks, has indicated in some detail what has happened to interest rates as a result of the Government's policies and the disastrous impact that that in turn has had on home buyers, in particular, on which he concentrated. I do not propose to say anything further on that matter, in the interests of economy. I am saving my words for some other areas on which the same disastrous impact has been applied, in particular small businesses and farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be quite clear as to where the responsibility for the present level of interest rates lies. Some members of the Australian Labor Party want to blame the banks for this unfortunate state of affairs. Senator Jenkins appeared to go a little in the same direction in her remarks, although I thought she was a little ambivalent. In any case, sticking with the Government's view of these matters, what we are seeing at present is the usual desperate search for scapegoats. The Government is in deep trouble and wants to find somebody to blame-anybody but the Labor Party. From time to time the banks are trotted out as the scapegoats. From time to time the multinational corporations are trotted out as the scapegoats. Even some of our own major corporate borrowers have been trotted out from time to time although the Labor Party has to be a little careful there because the association of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) with most of the major leading figures concerned is well known and on the record. Name it-there is a scapegoat somewhere. But honourable senators can bet their lives that it is not the Labor Party! It happens to have been governing this country only for the last 6 1/2 years! In truth, it is the fault of none of those scapegoats; it is the fault of the Hawke-Keating Labor Government-that Government, and it alone.

Many points were made about borrowings being made by business corporations. Of course borrowings are made overseas by business corporations. They have to be because, under the policies of this Government, we have a deficit on the current account of our balance of payments-that is, we are importing more than we can afford. That has to be financed under the policies of this Government. If those corporations were not borrowing, somebody else would have to. In the end, if no private individual corporations borrowed, the Government would have to, or it would have to change its policies. Of course, that is what it should do; it should change its policies so as to remove the need for these borrowings.

Yesterday the Prime Minister, who has not yet reached the point of crying on television about this subject, although no doubt that too will happen in due course, was in Ballarat. An article in this morning's Australian Financial Review by Geoff Kitney has some interesting comments about that. Apparently Mr Hawke yesterday lunched with a struggling home-buying family in Ballarat. Imagine the pitiful scene of the Prime Minister lunching with a struggling home-buying family in Ballarat. That would be a sight to be seen. Mr Kitney was not very impressed by this piece of drama on the Prime Minister's part, because he begins his article, entitled `Hawke's ``hold on and hope'' strategy', by saying:
The Hawke Government is adrift. It is unsure what is happening to the Australian economy and uncertain how to respond to the economic and political challenges ahead.
We can say that in spades. Mr Kitney goes on:
The sense of drift was apparent in comments by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, yesterday after he had lunched-
no doubt it was gruel-

with a struggling home-buying family in Ballarat. `I explained to them, and I think they understand, that we've just got to hold on for while until we get this level of activity down,' Mr Hawke said. `I just hope that we're going to see that before too long.'
Mr Kitney went on to say that the Prime Minister's comments encapsulated the sense of frustration and doubt that has gripped the Government. He went on:
The perception of the Government wringing its hands and hoping something will turn up is growing. There is mounting concern within the federal bureaucracy that this is indeed the reality.

Some senior bureaucrats believe the Government is dying. The only comment I would have about that perception on the part of the senior bureaucrats concerned is that I think the Government died at least two years ago. That is why there has been this increasing smell over the state of our economy-there are some dead governments around. Mr Kitney continued:
There is certainly an overwhelming case for the Government to be seen to be responding to the economic problems more decisively than indicated by Mr Hawke's comments yesterday.
Later on he said:
It cannot afford to be seen to be as paralysed by indecision and uncertainty. It must respond to these perceptions and show it still has a clear sense of purpose and direction.
Another one of Mr Hawke's more choice remarks yesterday was reported as follows by Mr Kitney:
`I'm not going to dodge the hard but right decisions for some perceived temporary political popularity,' Mr Hawke said yesterday.

I seem to have heard words of that kind before. I remember the Prime Minister addressing the nation on television on 11 June 1986 when he was trying to put down the unfortunate effects of the banana republic comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). On that occasion he finished his speech with a statement which I think-I have not had the time to compare it-was almost word for word with his speech yesterday. Three years later we are still getting the same literally tired rhetoric from our Prime Minister, so much so that the Australian newspaper this morning, which I do not think has been unfriendly to the Government, was moved to head its leading article with `Why does Bob feel so good about himself?'. It begins its comment upon yesterday's events by quoting from an interview which Mr Hawke gave to Mr Paul Kelly, the senior political correspondent of the Australian, and which was published in the Australian yesterday. Mr Hawke is quoted in that interview, and again in this leading article this morning, as follows:

`We've been so successful in getting so much of macro-economic policy right,' the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said in an interview with Paul Kelly in the Australian yesterday, `getting growth, getting jobs, getting restructuring . . .'

Then the writer of the leading article goes on to ask, not unnaturally, why, if everything is so right, Australia has `record foreign debt, record domestic interest rates and a continuing balance of payments near-crisis despite favourable terms of trade? If things are so good, why do they feel so bad?'. The leader writer drew the conclusion:

Mr Hawke is, in fact, displaying extraordinary and worrying complacency about the state of the nation. Self-congratulation seems to be his opiate and he is on the brink of sedating himself into total inertia.
He says finally:
Difficult times demand strong leaders not smug ones who have put their feet up.

TALK.START.PARA: —What article is that?

—The leading article in this morning's Australian newspaper. Is there any hope for this Government? Is there any hope for Australia under this Government? In particular, is there any hope of lower interest rates under the present Government's policies? The answer to that question is: only if and when there occurs the recession to which the Government's policies are otherwise inevitably leading us. This is because for the past 12 months the Government has stuck stubbornly to the line that everything has been okay; nothing is wrong; all we need is another turn of the interest rate screw. The result has been that what began as an unbalanced set of policies is now a totally unbalanced set of policies: the Government's spending has not been cut; wages and salaries are set to rise by 7 1/2 or 8 per cent in the financial year just ahead of us; and there is not a particle of micro-economic reform, notwithstanding all the promises in the last week or so about reform at some time on the waterfront or in coastal shipping-none of which will do more than manage to keep us within sight of the rest of the world, which is disappearing over the horizon, beating us into the ground.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of high interest rates on small businesses and farmers has been catastrophic. We are all very much aware, because it is a matter of much more popular comment, that housing loan rates have risen by 3 1/2 percentage points in the last 12 months-from 13 1/2 to 17 per cent. However, interest rates being paid by small businesses have risen by 7 or 7 1/2 percentage points during that time. Whether one looks at overdraft rates or bank bill rates, one finds that that has been roughly the magnitude of the rise-7 percentage points. Can one imagine the effect of that kind of increase in the cost of financing a small business-that includes farmers, who quintessentially are small businessmen for the most part-on its operations? Just imagine what that is now doing for the lifeblood of those businesses and farms.

What is the outlook? What hope can realistically be held out at present under the Government's policies? The latest issue of the Commonwealth Bank's economic newsletter was released to the media yesterday. That newsletter is written by the economics department of a major bank, a government-owned bank, and it is known for the sobriety and responsibility of its comments. It is not given to scare articles or anything of that kind. What has the Commonwealth Banking Corporation had to say through its own official channels? Among other things, it states:

Australia will be walking an economic tightrope in 1989/90. On one side is the risk that demand pressures will fail to ease sufficiently in the short-run to stabilize the current account deficit, eventually triggering a currency crisis that would guarantee a hard landing for the economy. On the other is the risk of interest rate `overkill'-the possibility that the further rise in interest rates over recent months will eventually tip the economy into recession.
It goes on to talk about the precarious outlook for the economy and about the policy response over the past 12 months. It states:
The policy response has primarily centred on a painstakingly gradual tightening of monetary policy, the first moves in this direction having commenced well over 12 months ago.
The progressive rise in interest rates has to date had little impact on economic activity.
The newsletter then mentions the increasing urgency of the task on which the Government has embarked in this lame way. It states:
The sharp rise in Australia's foreign debt over the past year has increased the urgency of the adjustment task . . . Policy is therefore likely to be tightened further, if unambiguous-
the Treasurer used that word at the Premiers Conference only a month ago-
signs of a slowing in domestic demand do not appear soon . . . At the very least, there will be no scope for any easing of policy for at least the balance of 1989.

A little further on the newsletter sets down the Commonwealth Banking Corporation's forecasts-the forecasts of its economic department-for this financial year, which is almost completed now of course, and for the next financial year, 1989-90. It is fascinating to see that, first of all, it forecasts a balance of payments current account deficit this year of $17.2 billion. The bank forecasts a deficit of $17.5 billion for next year also. There is no relief at all there. Some of the other figures are even more fascinating. It forecasts a rise in the consumer price index this year of 7.3 per cent. That should not come as any surprise, although it is higher than the 1987-88 figure, notwithstanding the Treasurer's promise to bring it down by 2 1/2 percentage points. For 1989-90 the bank forecasts another rise of 7.2 per cent. There are a number of other forecasts, including one for employment growth of 0.9 per cent. We all know that the Australian work force is growing much faster than that, so that is a forecast of developing unemployment in 1989-90. Indeed, the bank itself says:
For calendar year 1990-
which is six months further on still-
growth-
that is, growth in the domestic product-
is expected to be under 1% (the equivalent of a `growth-recession').

A growth recession is one in which production is still rising somewhat, but not fast enough to absorb the increase in the work force. We have an economy which is out of control and which the Government is totally at a loss to know how to handle. It has locked itself into a high interest rate policy. It has no other response and the consequence is that we are heading into a recessionary phase which the Government is totally at a loss to know how to counteract. The effect of this on small businesses and farmers will be disastrous, and the effect on mortgagors has already been demonstrated at some length by my colleague Senator Michael Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stone, as is usual, has given a very lucid account of his position and has asked: Is there any hope for this Government? At least that question can be asked about this Government. If the Opposition were in government, the country would have absolutely no hope. The terms of the matter of public importance are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on homebuyers, small businesses and farmers.

I will not say that the present interest rate has no effect on people-of course it has. Of course it is hurting people and of course it is hard for people buying homes. Of course it is hard for people borrowing money to have to pay the high interest rates that are presently operating. But that situation is this Government's answer to the needs of the economy at the moment. It has taken a responsible attitude. It has taken a line which, in spite of being electorally disadvantageous, is part of its overall policy of bringing this country, this economy, and its people into a happier time-certainly happier than that under the previous Government.

It is unfortunate for the country that today the Opposition has repeated its usual tactic in this chamber. Opposition members are mighty in rhetoric but very meek in action. Their rhetoric has pointed out all the hardships people are suffering and all the difficulties the country faces, but they never give an answer. This debate is a bit like the debate we had earlier in the week on the reform of the waterfront industries. Senator Chaney, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, said there was a drastic need for reform in areas such as the waterfront, coastal shipping and the operations of government enterprises. He said things were disastrous. He said there were scandals, but he never got around to giving us an answer. In a vague way, he said, `Well, we'll adopt what the Inter-State Commission says'. Reading his speech is like reading some sort of article which says, `See schedule 1 in some other document'.

We will never find the answer in the speeches from those opposite. All Opposition members do is point out the difficulty the country is in. That is not to be denied. Of course, it is in difficulty. What the Opposition should be doing in this chamber is giving answers.

What would the Opposition do? Would it fix interest rates if it came to power? Would it fix interest rates at 5 per cent, 10 per cent, 12.5 per cent or 13.5 per cent? Would it put quotas on imports? If so, at what level and on which imports would it put quotas? Would it fix exchange rates? Would it abolish the fringe benefits tax? Would it abolish the capital gains tax? Would it increase unemployment as a way out of the present difficulty? Would it lower social security benefits? Would it go to the wall with the unions? Would it lower wages? Would it introduce essential services legislation? Would it gaol people who would not work for low wages? What exactly would the Opposition do? We could have some great debates in this chamber if specific items were put up for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A statement of policy.

—A general statement of policies, plus some specific terms of those policies as to how they would operate. Unfortunately, we never get them, which makes it very difficult. It is always easy to condemn, to point out defects and say things are not going as well as they should be. It is a lot more helpful if specific proposals can be put which perhaps could be adopted by the Government or, at least, put to the people of Australia so that they would know what the situation is.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to read an interview reported in the Australian Financial Review on Monday, 29 May 1989, with Dr Hewson, who is the shadow Treasurer. It is interesting to see the sorts of things he said about interest rates, for example. He said:

As a lot of what has happened on interest rates has been to bolster the confidence of foreigners in this country, then their attitudes would shift as well. You have the capacity for reasonably early reductions in interest rates as a result of that confidence.

We are debating a matter of public importance brought on today condemning the Government on interest rates, and what did the shadow Treasurer say on Monday, 29 May 1989? He did not say that he would reduce interest rates tomorrow, or next week. He said that, if things are put in place in a particular way, then there would be the capacity for a reasonably early reduction in interest rates as a result of increased confidence. The point I make is that, if Dr Hewson became Treasurer tomorrow, he would pursue the same policy on interest rates as this Government is pursuing now. That is what he said in that interview. He would hope, as this Government hopes, that there would be a reasonably early reduction in interest rates.

When the members of the Opposition condemn this Government, as they are attempting to do in this debate, for the rates at which interest is charged in Australia at the moment, why do they not say, as their proposed Treasurer did in his interview on 29 May, that if they came to government they would maintain interest rates at the level they now are until a reasonably early time, they would hope, in the future? Dr Hewson goes on in the next paragraph to say:
I don't want to pretend, however, that there are any instantaneous solutions because there aren't.
In that interview on Monday, 29 May, reported in the Financial Review Dr Hewson, the shadow Treasurer, said that there are no instantaneous solutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can there be after six years of the policies of your Government, for goodness sake? One hundred and three billion dollars of debt. How can that possibly be instantaneously solved?

—Senator Stone asked the reasonable question: What have we done in six years? Why are we in this position after six years, going on for seven, of this Government? The point is that had the Opposition been in government during that period, things would be absolutely disastrous. There would not have been wage restraints; there would not have been employment growth; there would not have been a reduction in the number of industrial disputes; there would not have been a reduction in unit labour costs of 9.2 per cent; there would not have been 1.3 million new jobs created; and there would not have been a growth rate twice that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and four times that achieved by the Liberals when they were in government. Neither would there have been a 60 per cent reduction in industrial disputes. Had the Liberal Party been in power over the last six years none of those things would have happened.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely undeniable that we are still in difficulties. There is a need for drastic solutions and that is what we aim for with the increased interest rates. But the interest rate increase is not necessarily as vicious and as draconian as it might otherwise have been had a Liberal-National Party government been in office for the last six years. Over the last six years this Government has reached a situation where at least there is light at the end of the tunnel. Had the situation been different there would have been no light at the end of the tunnel; in fact, the tunnel probably would have been blocked completely.
Let me go back to the article by Dr Hewson, his analysis of the economy and his solutions. He has said that, if the coalition came into Government:
A lot of things would happen simultaneously. It would be a co-ordinated group of ministers working. You'd have John Moore in a privatisation area . . .

I take it from that that the Opposition would privatise everything very quickly; in fact, it might even privatise the Senate and we would be paid-and this is what worries me-according to how we perform. That is something that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber would want to avoid, so we really have to be careful as to how far we take privatisation. What we could do is put advertisements on the backs of our seats so that when the cameras zoomed in on us people could see whatever we were advertising. Senator Hill could have on the back of his seat, `Senator Hill's hit men'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Hill's hoist.

—Yes, or `Hill's hoist'. Senator Stone could have `Senator Stone's tuition school'. Senator Panizza could have `The Panizza farm tuition college', and things such as that. I would certainly be proud to have any of those placards on the back of my seat.
—What would you put on the back of yours?
—I would have to put on the back of my seat--
—Order! The honourable senator will address his remarks to the Chair.
—In any event, if the Opposition came into government it would introduce full scale privatisation. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Chaney on the industrial relations side . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney.

—That is how his name is rendered in this article. I do not have any disrespect for Senator Fred Chaney; indeed, I have nothing but admiration for him, but that is the way his name is written in the interview.
—What?
—Senator Walsh asks, `What?'. I am like Senator Walsh. We have nothing but high regard-indeed, love-for the Opposition. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Chaney on the industrial relations side who'd move reasonably quickly with compliance and other legislation, giving people the option of either staying in the system or going out, and Andrew Peacock who has worked in all these areas.

Andrew Peacock, who was an outstanding shadow Treasurer, a man who is very learned in this area of economics, said, `If workers are to stay in the system, the arbitration rules should be changed so that the Industrial Relations Commission would be required to take account of productivity and the impact of international competitiveness'. Therefore, workers, wages, and people would have to give way to the rigours of international competition. It would not matter what they required to live a reasonable life; that would be irrelevant. Workers would be given $10 a week, if it was necessary, to enable companies to stay internationally competitive. The next part of Dr Hewson's statement is what really surprised me. Over the years, we have put the accord forward as the basis for the way we have acted. Again and again, the Opposition has said, `You've got to abandon the accord; the unions are irresponsible; it's a disastrous program; the unions have brought us to this pass'. This is what Dr Hewson had to say about this:

It's a different world, that's true, but that is not necessarily going to cause a wage explosion or an increase in interest rates, and I expect that the union movement would give us the same sort of break or their attitude will be as conciliatory as the business community was to Labor when they came in.

You won't have the unions going out the door on Day 1 and pulling a national strike. It is a different union movement today, they know their role, they know their limitations, they have learned from 1981 so you are dealing with a reasonably mature situation.

This is the sort of thing that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would agree with. According to Dr Hewson, the trade union movement, in its mature way, has been the basis for what has occurred and will be the basis for the way Australia goes ahead in the future. In other words, what the Opposition is saying when it comes down to it is that if it gets into power it will adopt the very policies that we are putting forward now. It is not able to state alternative policies because it really has not got any--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cooney, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance brought to it today by Senator Michael Baume in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy on home buyers, small businesses and farmers.

In other words, we are debating the disastrous impact of the Government's high interest rate policy and deliberate policy on three sectors of our community, that is, home buyers, small business people and farmers. I repeat the terms of that matter of public importance because, having just listened to Senator Cooney, one could have wondered whether that was the subject of the debate. Senator Cooney is always fun to listen to. He always makes a contribution which is amusing. But, unfortunately, in no way did he seek to wrestle with the matter that was before the Senate. The matter before the Senate is the Government's record, which is angering the Australian community, and very reasonably so, as we will demonstrate.

One would have thought that Senator Maguire, who spoke a little earlier, with his economic background, might have tried to address the issue. But, unfortunately, he resorted to his standard economic history lesson rather than try to address the Government's very dramatic failure in this area which is so critically affecting the Australian community. One might wonder how it has come about that honourable senators on the other side are unable to wrestle with the matter. It seems that a government in office too long loses touch with its grassroots. When one listened to Senator Maguire one could not help but think that what he said would not mean a thing to Australians listening to this debate who are paying 17 per cent on their housing interest bill and struggling or, alternatively, small businesses which are paying 22 or 23 per cent on their overdraft rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Farmers are paying 24 per cent.

—Or farmers like the ones that I have on the west coast of South Australia, who had four years of drought and were paying not only an overdraft rate of 22 per cent but also, because they were all in default-not having had an income for four years-were having to pay a couple of extra per cent on top of it. They are not actually paying it at all because they have not got any money. It simply gets added to the bill so that when their property is ultimately sold from under them someone gets something out of it. These are the Australians who are being affected by this Government's deliberate policies. It is astonishing that this Government does not seem to understand that reality.

SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said in the last day it becomes so dramatically illustrated. It was mentioned in earlier debate here today. It was certainly mentioned in Question Time when reference was made to the Prime Minister speaking in Bendigo, He said that the Australian community should use its yet to be received tax cuts to offset the burden of record interest rates, spend some and then save the rest. He said, `From your tax cuts you will be able to offset the Government's record interest rates. You will have some money left to spend and after that you will be able to make some savings'.

My colleague Senator Crichton-Browne put to the Senate some figures on this particular matter in Question Time today. He pointed out that a single income earner supporting two children, earning $35,000 a year and paying off a mortgage of $40,000-that sounds to be a reasonably typical Australian; perhaps that person is earning a little more than a typical Australian-will receive a tax cut of $25.65. The increase in that family's mortgage will be $25.15. That family will have 50c from which the Prime Minister says, `Spend some and then save the rest'. As Senator Panizza will say if they go out and invest their 50c they will be paying 40 per cent of what they get in income in income tax. It is absolutely farcical. It shows a government out of touch with the Australian community and a Prime Minister out of touch. One can only presume that this has come about simply because the Government has been in office too long, spent too much time in the ivory tower and does not appreciate the consequences of its policies upon the average Australian.

What is so incredible in this whole exercise is that the policy to deliberately push up interest rates is a deliberate government policy. It has been adopted in an effort, we are told, to slow growth within the community. But that is not a growth that has been caused by the small consumers and the ordinary home owner who has to pay off a mortgage. It is a different cause altogether. That is why we have said before, and we repeat it, that this instrument of economic policy being used by the Government to remedy its own economic deficiencies is a blunt policy instrument which has been heartlessly wielded to hurt a mass of innocent Australians.

Senator Reid and I saw this in Canberra last week when we attended a meeting of one of the many consumer action groups which are springing up around Australia at the moment to protest against this Government's policy and attitude over interest rates. There were about 1,500 Canberra residents there. Most of them paid high interest. It was interest that they had agreed with their bank to pay in the range of about 13 1/2 per cent 12 months ago. They are now paying 17 per cent; but they cannot pay it. They cannot meet the difference. They did not expect the difference probably because they relied on the promises of this Prime Minister.

I remind honourable senators that when the Western Australian election came around Prime Minister Hawke said, `Interest rates will come down'. That is probably technically true but he did not say when they were going to come down or that they would go up many percentage points in the meantime. They have not come down as he promised. In fact they have gone up and are continuing to go up. The average Australians whom we saw out in the suburbs of Canberra last week are struggling as a result of them. What was the reaction of the Australian home owners in Canberra? When speaking of this Government they chanted, `Out, out'. They are sick and tired of the fact that this Government does not appreciate that the deliberate policy it has adopted is forcing them out of their homes. They are unable to meet the payments upon the homes which are so critical to them and to the maintenance and sustainability of their families.

The nonsense goes on. We have had the Prime Minister, I gather in the last 24 hours, saying that he sees no need for interest rates to go higher. How many times have we heard that from him? Again in this chamber we have Senator Button saying something similar. My colleague Senator Reid asked why a Government member or a Government Minister would not turn up at that protest meeting in Canberra and face the 1,500 angry home owners and try to explain this deliberate high interest rate policy of the Government? Of course, the answer did not come. Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in this chamber, simply said that he could see no reason why a Labor member should attend and listen to those concerned. Mr Acting Deputy President, I would have thought that you would have attended. Surely you have some sensitivity towards people who are struggling and who are facing the prospect of being thrown out of their homes. But that is not the formal attitude of this Government; it says it is better to avoid facing up to that responsibility, to remain deaf, to close one's eyes rather than face the consequences of the Government's deliberate policy.
It has been drawn to my attention that the rally which took place in Canberra is now moving on to Tasmania. One person has had recorded in the Tasmanian press her personal position:
Single mother of two Cheryl Nebauer, of Hagley, works two jobs to repay her 17 per cent home loan. If it hits 18 per cent, as the banks are touting, she will be forced to sell her home.
She said:
I can't handle 17 per cent, let alone 18 per cent. It's heartbreaking to have put five years of my life into it and watch it go . . .
That is the sort of person this arrogant Government ought to listen to. As the writer of the article said:
Cheryl is just one of hundreds of thousands of Australians now faced with selling personal possessions or foregoing life's necessities in order to meet home loan interest repayments.

What were her circumstances? She took out her loan at 14 per cent on the strength of a Hawke Government promise that home loan interest rates would not be increased. Yet they have been deliberately forced up by this Government. About 50 per cent of mortgages in Australia were taken out after April 1986, the time of deregulation. Rates are now up to 17 per cent and Australians cannot pay the difference. What will be the cost of this policy to Australian families?

If one reads the reports of the Australian Institute of Family Studies, the advice of the Economic Planning Advisory Council or the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on homeless kids, the message is the same: financial hardship will eventually break up families. Families will not be able to withstand ultimately the financial stress. It is not surprising that we see such a respected member of the community as the Bishop of Tasmania, the Right Reverend Phillip Newell, giving us the sort of reminder that this Government should be listening to. He said:
Financial pressures were a major cause of marital breakdown in today's society, and as much as possible should be done to protect families from such pressures.

That is not the approach of this Government. In order to try to solve an economic problem it has made, it has adopted one lone blunt instrument of economic policy-driving up interest rates. In doing so it is affecting those who presumably it did not intend to affect-or perhaps it did; I do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —It probably did.

—Perhaps it did. They are the mass of normal Australian families who have as their most cherished possession their home, something that is critical to maintaining their family position and security. We in the Opposition recognise that this country is in an economic mess. We recognise that drastic action is necessary. I am pleased that Senator Cooney said that we recognised that. With balance of payment figures this year showing about an $18 billion deficit and with the country over $100 billion in debt, we recognise that something has to be done. We also recognise that the Australian Democrats' answer of some sort of artificial cap is not going to be a satisfactory answer and will not provide a long-term solution. It will only provide another distortion and a prejudice against those who still have to rent. If interest rate deduction is allowed, how will we meet our responsibility to the 160,000 Australians who are on public housing waiting lists at the moment? That is a deplorable figure.

SPEECH.PARA: The economy has to be got back in order. It has to become efficient again and become competitive. Incentives must be given to get it back in order. There must be proper restraint on public expenditure and reform to the barriers such as the transport industry and the waterfront. We have got to lift productivity and become internationally competitive. Without that Australians will continue to suffer.
